headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Second Quarter 2016 Financial Teleconference. My name is Tony, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Second Quarter 2016 Financial Teleconference. My name is Tony, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Scott Cunningham, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Cunningham, you may begin your conference.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Welcome, everyone. Our principal speakers today will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here are other members of the management team.Materials
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Welcome, everyone. Our principal speakers today will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here are other members of the management team.
Materials supporting today's call are available at www.edisoninvestor.com. These include our Form 10-Q, Ted and Jim's prepared remarks, and the presentation that accompanies Jim's comments. Tomorrow afternoon, we will distribute our regular business update presentation. 
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements about the future outlook for Edison International and its subsidiaries. Actual results could differ materially from current expectations. Important factors that could cause different results are set forth in our SEC filings. Please read these carefully. The presentation includes certain outlook assumptions as well as reconciliations of GAAP and non-GAAP measures [Operator Instructions] With that, I'll turn the call over to Ted.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Second quarter results were below last year's results as we expected. You will recall that we told investors in our First Quarter Earnings Call that quarterly year-over-year comparisons would not be all that
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Second quarter results were below last year's results as we expected. You will recall that we told investors in our First Quarter Earnings Call that quarterly year-over-year comparisons would not be all that meaningful. This is primarily due to timing mismatches, including: Impacts from the delayed decision on SCE's 2015 to '17 rate case; the significant SCE tax benefits recorded last year but not repeated this year; no Edison capital asset sales this year versus last year; and the timing of Edison Energy costs versus revenues.
The larger point that I want to leave with you is that core earnings are on track for the full year. That is why today we reaffirmed our full year core earnings guidance range of $3.81 to $4.01 earnings per share. In fact, based on second quarter results, although there are various puts and takes amongst the businesses, our current outlook indicates that consolidated results for the full year are in the top half of our guidance range. However, consistent with what we have done in several of the past years, we will hold off until our third quarter results are in to decide if we should adjust our core earnings guidance. 
We are in the final half of our 2015 to '17 CPUC rate case period. We have communicated to investors that based on CPUC-approved capital spending and expected spending on FERC jurisdictional transmission projects, we expect rate base growth -- rate base to grow approximately 7% in the 2016 to '17 period. This still seems appropriate. We have communicated several times in the past that there is relatively little variance expected in the timing of CPUC jurisdictional spending for the 2016 to '17 period, but more variability is possible in the timing but less likely in the ultimate amount of our FERC jurisdictional transmission spending. Remember, SCE's transmission investment is to improve system reliability and bring online utility scale wind and solar resources to meet California's aggressive renewable energy targets. Most of the transmission CapEx spending variability occurs due to delays in routing decisions and permitting approvals at the state and federal levels. A recent example was the $1.1 billion West of Devers project, which is something of a moving target with CPUC staff even with KISO [ph] support, but appears ready for final CPUC approval with a supportive alternate proposed decision pending.
We see scheduled challenges of this sort for other lesser transmission projects as well. Net-net, we don't expect meaningful impacts to our total transmission spend expectations over the medium-term 3- to 5-year period, but likely some shifting between the years. Said differently, our current view is that 2016 rate base will not be materially different than forecasted. 2017 could be slightly lower, but recovered in the 2018 to 2020 period. 
On the last earnings call, most of my comments were devoted to outlining the future SCE growth opportunity. I'd like to provide some additional comments today, keeping in mind that we will be able to elaborate more on this when SCE makes its general rate case filing on September 1. 
In the broadest sense, the capital spending request in our 2018 to 2020 general rate case is designed to help California achieve its low carbon policy objectives and to enable customer choice while continuing to focus on reliable and affordable service for all customers. Keeping it simple, the requested investment can be lumped into 2 buckets. The first bucket is comprised of grid investments we have traditionally requested in past rate cases. The second bucket is made up of new grid modernization investments. Let me expand further on these 2 areas. 
The traditional investments we will propose in the first bucket represent the vast majority of our total rate case capital spending request. The areas of spending encompass 5 basic elements: Replacement of aging infrastructure; new customer connections and demand growth on certain circuits; investments in information technology to improve customer service and cost efficiency; maintenance capital spending on SCE's generation fleet; and other core investments such as in our operations facilities.
This first bucket of requested spending, together with other non-GRC spending such as SCE's electric vehicle charging program and FERC transmission spending, is expected to total more than $4 billion in CapEx per year. It is difficult to handicap how much of our requested investment in this first bucket of capital spending will ultimately be approved. However, investors have some history to observe in this regard. SCE received 81% of its requested capital spending in the 2009 to '11 rate case, 89% of its 2012 to '14 general rate case requests, and 92% of its 2015 to '17 requests. 
The smaller second bucket of spending we will request is new. It is for modernization of the distribution system and is part of SCE's strategy to facilitate the growth of distributed energy resources. Governor Brown and the California legislature have stated their strong desire for California to lead the nation in developing policies to create a low carbon economy while creating jobs and prosperity for its citizens. SB 350, signed into law last year, stated the goal of making the electric grid a key enabler of California's low carbon policy ambitions, including by electrifying transportation. The CPUC has 2 active proceedings underway, which together will help shape the long-term planning for this vision. 
From a capital investment perspective, the most important is the distribution resources plan proceeding. In this proceeding, the CPUC's stated goal is to modernize the distribution system during the next decade, but it provided only some early direction on preferred technologies and required investments.
SCE, through its 2018 to 2020 General Rate Case, will be the first electric utility to provide specificity for how this technology evolution should unfold. This will be the new element of our September 1 filing. We need to wait until that filing to be specific about the amount and details of our investment request, but you should expect that the overall level of the request will be roughly consistent with our DRP filing last summer. At this time, based on the pace of grid modernization that SCE will described in its 2018 GRC filing, it is expected that grid modernization capital expenditures and rate base growth will continue beyond 2025. 
Some of the requested grid modernization investment would be better characterized as reinforcing the existing system, such as upgrading low voltage circuits in order to accommodate higher penetration of distributed energy resources. But other parts really have no precedent, and therefore we do not know how to handicap how much of our request might finally be approved. 
Like any technology evolution, there are certain initial investments that need to be made to create the foundational infrastructure that will support systemwide grid modernization. SCE has identified the critical path that it believes needs to get started sooner rather than later. That is what led SCE to file on July 13 for a memorandum account requesting authority from the CPUC to track certain early-stage investment cost ahead of its 2018 General Rate Case filing. The July 13's request points out that the process of modernizing the distribution grid requires some near-term planning, engineering, procurement and installation of certain distribution system upgrades before the 2018 SCE-GRC period. SCE's July 13 filing request authority to track the revenue requirement of approximately $100 million of capital spending to be placed in service in 2017 that is critical to meeting the CPUC's overall timeline for grid modernization. If the memorandum account is approved and expenditures are deemed prudent, the associated rate base will be included in either the 2018 or perhaps the 2021 General Rate Case filing.
I'll finish with comments on 2 other matters. The first is SONG. Last week we, and other parties, completed briefings requested by the CPUC. The Court question was whether the SONG settlement, unanimously approved by the CPUC, was still reasonable given the various disclosures about ex-parte communications made last year. There were 6 signatories to the SONG settlement. 4 of the 6 settling parties, San Diego Gas and Electric, Friends of the Earth, The Coalition of California Utility Employees and SCE, submitted filings that made clear why these communications had no impact on the settlement process and why the settlement remains reasonable, lawful and in the public interest. Two of the settling parties turned an ROA are seeking on their filings to impose additional penalties on SCE. We strongly believe this is opportunistic and inappropriate. We also note that before approving the settlement, the commission asked the settling parties to amend the settlement in meaningful ways, all of which were more favorable for customers, which the parties ultimately did. The commission then unanimously approved that amended settlement. 
While there remains no timeline for further action, we are hopeful that the commission will see the record as demonstrating the validity and appropriateness of the settlement by reaffirming the settlement and dismissing the pending appeals. 
The final item is the important CPUC reforms announced in late June by the governor and key legislators and subsequently, endorsed by the CPUC. These reforms largely address a series of principles the governor has advocated while balancing sensitivities over the role of the executive and legislative branches in designing and implementing these reforms. While there are many details yet to be finalized, the overall approach appears responsive. If implemented as described, it should continue to provide broad public access to the decision-making process, accelerate timely decision-making, address important CPUC staffing and recruiting issues and allow CPUC commissioners more leeway to discuss important topics amongst themselves. 
This concludes my remarks. Jim will now provide his financial update.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ted, and hello, everyone. My comments today will cover second quarter and year-to-date results, earnings guidance and our updated capital expenditures and rate base forecasts. Please turn to Page 2 of the presentation.As a brief reminder, compar
componenttext:
Thanks, Ted, and hello, everyone. My comments today will cover second quarter and year-to-date results, earnings guidance and our updated capital expenditures and rate base forecasts. Please turn to Page 2 of the presentation.
As a brief reminder, comparisons to 2015 will not be meaningful, primarily because of the timing of the 2015 GRC decision and the impact of taxes. I also explained last quarter how we've removed, in a variance analysis, the impact of prepared deductions, pole loading and incented on free tax items because these revenue items have offsets within the income statement. 
EIX's basic and core earnings per share are $0.85 for the second quarter or $0.31 per share less than the same quarter last year. SCE's second quarter basic and core earnings are $0.21 per share lower and EIX Parent and other are $0.10 per share lower. The lower earnings are primarily due to $0.31 per share of income tax benefits recorded in the second quarter of last year. 
Focusing on the SCE key EPS drivers column, the utilities revenue was $0.10 per share higher quarter-over-quarter. This increase includes $0.09 per share from a GRC attrition mechanism, which automatically adjusts authorized revenue following the 2015 test year. This is largely offset by a $0.06 per share timing issue with the 2015 GRC decision. As I discussed last quarter, authorized revenue reductions from the 2015 GRC decision are not reflected in results for the first four second quarter of this year. You'll see the reversed in the third and fourth quarters of this year. There is also a $0.03 per share positive variance from the pole loading balancing account. This balancing account was created with the final 2015 GRC decision, so the $0.08 of pole loading earnings we had last year was all recorded in the fourth quarter. FERC revenue are $0.03 per share higher. This is largely related to revenues associated with a higher operating costs and abandoned plant recoveries for the canceled Coolwater-Lugo transmission project. The recovery of Coolwater-Lugo cost will continue through 2016 and has no impact on earnings. Together, these revenue items net to a positive $0.10 per share. 
O&M was not a major driver in the second quarter as lower legal and labor costs, due to workforce reductions, are mostly offset by a planned outage and upgrades at the Mountain View Generation Plant and higher pole loading costs. Results included $0.02 per share of severance costs comparable to what was recorded last year. Three of the $0.04 of higher depreciation are amortization of the Coolwater-Lugo cost discussed above. 
Net financing cost are $0.02 per share higher due primarily to an increase in the amount of preferred stock outstanding. The CPUC and FERC rate maintenance include funding for new debt and preferred stock to finance rate base growth. As indicated above, there was a $0.31 per share benefit from a change in uncertain tax positions in 2015. There is no comparable change in the second quarter of this year. Partially offsetting this item is a $0.04 per share benefit this year from tax depreciation and balancing accounts, bringing the net impact from income taxes to a negative $0.27.
The second quarter effective tax rate for SCE is a negative 9%, due primarily to a $133 million flow-through tax refund to customers for repair benefits from 2012 through 2014. The refund of tax repair benefits has no earnings impact. 
Higher insurance benefits primarily drive the $0.02 per share contribution from other income and expenses. This gets us to the $0.21 per share decline in the second quarter SCE earnings. 
I will turn next to EIX Parent and other. Losses increased by $0.10 per share overall from last quarter -- last quarter of last year. A key driver is a $0.04 per share buyout of an earnout provision with former shareholders and their current employees of a company acquired by Edison Energy at the end of 2015. The buyout was completed along with modification of employment contracts to align Edison Energy's incentive compensation with EIX's. The results are a penny per share of higher business development and operating costs. Comparisons are also affected by a $0.03 per share gain on the sale of a portion of Edison Capital's affordable housing portfolio during the second quarter of last year. 
Parent holding company costs increase by $0.02 per share due to higher interest expense as we termed out $400 million of holding company commercial paper debt and the impact of strong stock price performance on compensation expense. Core earnings exclude $0.01 per share of tax-related losses and discontinued operations related to the Edison Mission Energy getting to the net $0.10 per share of holding company losses. That, with a SCE variance, gets you to the $0.31 per share reduction in EIX earnings. 
Please turn to Page 3. I won't go into detail on the year-to-date results, but then to remind everyone that SCE's performance for the first half of 2016 is consistent with our full year SCE outlook which look stronger than our original guidance levels. At the same time, holding company costs are already at full year guidance levels or $0.18 per share. We've built both factors into our reaffirmed full year guidance. 
Please turn to Page 4. On top of this slide it shows our reaffirmed GAAP and core earnings guidance. However, our internal SCE earnings outlook will be above its $4.09 guidance midpoint, and holding company costs outlook will be higher than its guidance midpoint. We're comfortable reaffirming overall EIX earnings guidance for the full year based on this internal view. However, we have not updated our SCE and holding company guidance elements other than to indicate their directional trends. We are mindful that the third quarter is typically SCE's strongest of the year and we will continue our practice of looking to update guidance when we report third quarter results on November 1. 
As I previously mentioned, holding company year-to-date costs, including Edison Energy group, are at a full year guidance level of $0.18. Adjusting for an earnout agreement, which was not part of the original guidance, was lower year-to-date cost of $0.14. The important thing is that we do anticipate an increase in revenue during the second half of 2016 based on book deals and expected sales. I also want to point out that our guidance does not include any recoveries from the MHI arbitration. As a reminder, we are expensing all costs related to the arbitration as incurred through core earnings. For 2016 alone, we incurred $23 million of cost and a total of $76 million, including prior periods. As part of the SONGS settlement, we can recover our reasonable arbitration cost from MHI recoveries before sharing.
I will next touch on SCE's balance sheet strength. On June 30, SCE's weighted average common equity ratio was 50.3% versus the authorized level of 48%. This helps provide financial flexibility as the utility continues to fund growth with operating cash flow and retain earnings and without the need of new common equity. 
Please turn to Page 5. SCE has updated its capital spending forecast. We expect that 2016 will be lower by $300 million, and '17 will be $100 million higher. The biggest factor change, forecast change, is $375 million of transmission spending, mostly due to licensing delays of projects like Aubur Hill [ph], Mesa and the City of Riverside projects. As Ted has highlighted, we firmly believe these projects will ultimately move forward, and the balance of their capital spending will be shifted into our 2018 through '20 period.
We have also adjusted the utility's CPUC capital expenditures to more closely align with what the commission has authorized for the 3-year General Rate Case cycle. The net result of these changes is a reduction of approximately $200 million. 
Please turn to Page 6. You'll see that rate base has a directionally similar adjustment with the 2017 rate base forecast to be lower by $200 million. Because of the transmission delays, the reduction in rate base will be shifted into the 2018 through '20 period. As I mentioned earlier, we don't see this having any impact on 2016 earnings as the modest rate base reduction has more than offset in other areas based on SCE's current outlook.
I would like to add a short addendum to my prepared remarks. This earnings call is my 32nd and last CFO of EIX. It's been a great 8-year run. There's a lot of work that goes into each one of these calls and I'd like to recognize our Edison team that makes these calls happen. Personally, I think our disclosures and investment materials are among the best. This job falls to our lawyers, accountants, corporate communications folks and IR staff. In particular, our attorneys, Adam, Russ, Barbara, Kathleen, do a great job of converting accounting English into plain English. Our accountants, Aaron, Connie, Mark and Tricia make sure our books and SEC filings are in top shape. Our IR staff, Scott and Ally, do a fantastic job. As many of you know, Scott is a highly regarded IR professional and Ally has done a great job since joining us a year ago. 
I have always enjoyed the interaction with investors and analysts over the years. Hopefully you have earned our respect by the way we conduct our communications. Early on, Ted advised me, when communicating with investors and analysts, I should strive to keep my comments down at middle to fairway. Ted said if I push my comments left or right of center, you folks will sniff it out and our credibility will be called into question. I have tried to follow this solid advice and I hope Pedro and Maria will do the same. 
As you know, Ted and I are heading out on September 30. I don't have any plans for retirement yet, but there are many things that I want to do. The one thing that I would really like to do, though, is finally learn how to drive my golf balls down the middle of the fairway. 
Thank you, all. Operator, it's question time.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question would come from Julien Dumoulin-Smith.

componenttext: Thanks for the question. I can't give you much additional detail. As MHI did last year, they felt an obligation under the Tokyo Stock exchange rules to make a comment with respect to their view of their exposure onto the arbitration. We can't comment or confirm anything they've said in that filing. We are operating under a confidentiality order in the International Chamber of Commerce litigation that really precludes us from making any substantive comment. Sorry, I can't give you any more information.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No worries. I thought I have to ask. Separately, related and I feel compelled. I suppose that someone offered given the timing, can you pine a little bit on the desirability on the utilities and utility jurisdictions outside of California? To what extent
componenttext: No worries. I thought I have to ask. Separately, related and I feel compelled. I suppose that someone offered given the timing, can you pine a little bit on the desirability on the utilities and utility jurisdictions outside of California? To what extent is there, given the media headlines a desire to expand? Or deviate from the Edison Energy strategy you guys have previously articulated as being the go forward plan outside of SCE?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julienne, This is Ted. I'll weigh into that SCE question. I think we've been fairly open with investors over the years about our prospects. In a weird way, the most difficult element is we have tremendous growth prospects here at Southern California, Edis
componenttext: Julienne, This is Ted. I'll weigh into that SCE question. I think we've been fairly open with investors over the years about our prospects. In a weird way, the most difficult element is we have tremendous growth prospects here at Southern California, Edison. So our organic growth and the expected CAGRs from rate base and ultimately earnings really make looking at other utilities outside of our territory as more often than not looking dilutive, either to the underlying strategic approach that we have, which is, as you know, a wires-based focus or a delivery of electricity focus, rather than a heavy involvement in some of the other parts of the business, or dilutive from an earnings growth perspective. So as a result of that, we've continued to focus primarily on where we see the best opportunities, and those are really are our organic growth opportunities. I'll keep it at the 100,000-foot level. I certainly don't want to engage in speculation on any specific thing.

componenttext: Jim, all the best to all of you as well. First question, just to be clear, just clarifying a point you were making on parent. headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think what I'm indicating is that we had more expenses in the first half of the year. And you pulled out -- we said it was 18 [ph] and total for the first half, minus the $0.04 for essentially the onetime item, that gets you to 14 [ph]. And that's --
componenttext: So I think what I'm indicating is that we had more expenses in the first half of the year. And you pulled out -- we said it was 18 [ph] and total for the first half, minus the $0.04 for essentially the onetime item, that gets you to 14 [ph]. And that's -- I'm suggesting, I think I was trying to get to it in Steve's comment in question, that we're going to have more revenues in the second half of the year. So it's going to -- I've indicated it's going to be slightly above the $0.18 for the full year, but it's not going to be that much above.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then to get to the higher end of the range for the year, given that the parent drag will be higher, again would imply that you would be earning above your authorized ROE for this final year in this GRC. How much sort of basket you have to
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then to get to the higher end of the range for the year, given that the parent drag will be higher, again would imply that you would be earning above your authorized ROE for this final year in this GRC. How much sort of basket you have to further cut back on cost so you can continue to do that in the 3-year cycle of the GRC program? Which innings are we, as far as the cost reductions cycle is concerned?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's an ongoing process. I think when we started this 4 years ago, there was a lot to be done. And as you just look at our headcount, there's been a lot of reductions over the last 4 years. Compliments to Ron and the effort he started to continue with Ped
componenttext: It's an ongoing process. I think when we started this 4 years ago, there was a lot to be done. And as you just look at our headcount, there's been a lot of reductions over the last 4 years. Compliments to Ron and the effort he started to continue with Pedro. And there's more to be done. And what we keep fighting when we do these benchmarking studies, those in the first quartile keep getting more competitive. They continue to reduce their cost. So the job for us is they're even greater to keep up with them and then closing the ranks, because our goal here is to get to first quartile. So there's more to be done. And we've indicated it in our guidance for this year and we've indicated there will be some earnings from cost reductions next year's too. Of course we've passed that back as part of that 2018 GRC and then we started fresh looking for cost reductions.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: So what will happen on September 1, we'll file our application with the Public Utilities Commission. And concurrent with that, Brian, we will put out an 8-K providing additional information. So we'll probably pick up the capital expenditure forecast and the SEC rate base forecast. And then we'll cover the periods '15, '16, '17, '18, '19 and '20. So you'll have the full view and '15 was obviously authorized, it's just a base to start from. So you'll have a full 5-year forecasts. And we'll probably provide some additional detail in terms of some of the major components and the potential impact on bonus depreciation. So we're still developing that. But the current plan is to provide it concurrently with the GRC.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a little bit of a question kind of thinking about long-term capital spending levels. I mean, Ted, in your prepared remarks, are you implying that you think some of the capital spending levels will remain in the low $4 billion a year r
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a little bit of a question kind of thinking about long-term capital spending levels. I mean, Ted, in your prepared remarks, are you implying that you think some of the capital spending levels will remain in the low $4 billion a year range, or do you think it's when you make your 2018 rate case filing and you get into the DRP filing and docket that we're talking about something that's materially different from that level?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe some slightly different words but capture the same themes. What I was really trying to do in the prepared remarks is say just kind of keeping this thing simple. You should expect in our 2018 General Rate Case to see expenses kind of in 2 very broad
componenttext: Maybe some slightly different words but capture the same themes. What I was really trying to do in the prepared remarks is say just kind of keeping this thing simple. You should expect in our 2018 General Rate Case to see expenses kind of in 2 very broad buckets. One bucket is what I call pretty much traditional the meat and potato type investment request that we make every general rate case. So that covers kind of standard stuff, infrastructure replacement, expected demand, increases on certain of our circuits, new connections, so on and so forth. When you take that chunk together with the things that aren't in the GRC, such as the Charge Ready program and FERC Jurisdictional Transmission Spend, you should expect to see a number, generally in the neighborhood, maybe a little bit higher than what we have traditionally kind of talked about. So I'll just call that broadly the $4-billion-plus type of base number. Then, there's the second smaller bucket that you will see in the 2018 General Rate Case request, which will really going to be the first attempt to try to put some specificity around what is required to really modernize the distribution system, such that it can facilitate the state's carbon reduction goals and customer choice on technology. So distributed energy resources. And that's a lot harder for us at this early juncture to be able to handicap, one of that would ultimately be approved. So there's kind of the standard stuff, which when you lump it together with transmission spending and the like, it's going to look pretty similar to what you've seen in the past from us, maybe little bit higher. And then there's a new layer of stuff that really this rate case will kind of start that conversation about what that might look like. And that would be additive to the kind of base level. So this is what I signaled last earnings call and what we've elaborated on a little bit more in this earnings call.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you talk to customer groups and when you meet with some of the big parties, how flexible are they in terms of the balance need to modernize the distribution system, versus the impact of what that does on rates and therefore their own economics?
componenttext: And when you talk to customer groups and when you meet with some of the big parties, how flexible are they in terms of the balance need to modernize the distribution system, versus the impact of what that does on rates and therefore their own economics?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in a nutshell -- I didn't do it again here on this call, but last earnings call, I made a fairly evolved discussion about what has been the pace of electric rate increases relative to the pace of underlying consumer price index increases. And if you
componenttext: Yes, in a nutshell -- I didn't do it again here on this call, but last earnings call, I made a fairly evolved discussion about what has been the pace of electric rate increases relative to the pace of underlying consumer price index increases. And if you -- a lot of this depends in what you're starting with and where you're ending with. But as I said in the last call, when you look at the 1 year, the 5-year, the 10, the 20, the rate of increase in customer rates, the system average rate, has actually been at or below the rate of inflation, the Southern California Area CPI. I remember the 20 year number because that's kind of the most relevant one. So over the longer-term, that CPI increase, from '95 to '15, was 2.4% compound annual growth rate. The rate of increase in electric rates over that same '95 to '15 period was 2.0% CAGR compound annual growth rate. So as it kind of demonstrates over the long haul, we've been able to manage the price of electricity at or below the rate of inflation and that continues to be kind of our overall goal. Now you have periods where you get more of a surge and you get other periods where you end up consolidating some of those increases. But the key, I think, over the long haul is to have the price of electricity stay at or below the rate of inflation. That's our overall goal. That remains our goal.

componenttext: This is Ted. I'll just do something really quick here. I think most of the focus, most recently has been on SoCore. So that's our distributed solar generation company, and Edison Energy, which is the new venture that's focused on providing energy services to commercial and industrial customers. I think at this juncture, we may have made some comment about this in the last earnings call. But I think we feel encouraged based on customer reaction to the launch of Edison Energy, the C&I energy services business. But this isn't one of those things that is going to be built overnight. This is going to take some time. It really isn't, as we see at least, there isn't a category out there that addresses the market that we're trying to create. So it's going to take a little bit of time. But we're encouraged based on customer reaction and we're encouraged based on some deals that have been coming in the door in the last few months. So I'll just kind of leave it there. I don't think you should expect we'll be providing something every quarter on this. It's probably more likely to be maybe a couple of times a year as this thing progresses.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Pedro Pizarro. I would also add that we expect the kind of spending that we see in the next few years is going to be fairly foundational. And we'll provide more detail on that in the GRC. But even in what we put out there in our DRP filing last ye
componenttext: This is Pedro Pizarro. I would also add that we expect the kind of spending that we see in the next few years is going to be fairly foundational. And we'll provide more detail on that in the GRC. But even in what we put out there in our DRP filing last year and the materials that Jim was referencing earlier in our business update, if you take a look at the categories of spend there, particularly foundational. It's upgrading circuits, some of our older circuits that are lower voltage and need to be brought up to more modern standards in order to accommodate distributed energy resources. And it's also technology side things around our field area network, the communications infrastructure to having enough to handle the new devices out there. So I think that, that would hopefully provide some little narrower range in terms of the direction. But you're right, to the extent that priorities change through DRP or the policy filings that ultimately gets reflected in the GRCs.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mike, related to this and Ted mentioned this in his comments, is the memorandum account that we just recently filed. And we want to spend some capital and O&M dollars especially next year. It's really hard to step up in a material way to ramp-up a pro
componenttext: And Mike, related to this and Ted mentioned this in his comments, is the memorandum account that we just recently filed. And we want to spend some capital and O&M dollars especially next year. It's really hard to step up in a material way to ramp-up a program and you need to do it in steps. And that's what that memorandum account is really designed to do, to get us going and then give us a running start into the '18 GRC period. So that's an important milestone in what the commission does with that will be an important thing for our GRC.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, it was to make sure that all the acquired companies are incentivized around the earnings or the EBITDA for the entire Edison Energy enterprise. And we did the acquisitions. We did not have a long-term incentive plan established. We now have that b
componenttext: Really, it was to make sure that all the acquired companies are incentivized around the earnings or the EBITDA for the entire Edison Energy enterprise. And we did the acquisitions. We did not have a long-term incentive plan established. We now have that based on Edison Energy earnings in total and we felt it was best where there were individual earnouts that were aligned around goals of the earnings for that entity only did not line up with our broader integrated and cross-selling model. So we felt it best to transition everyone to the Edison Energy long-term incentive program and get out of the earnout.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ron. On the broader question of core versus noncore, given the size of this, there's a number of items that we have during any year where there are questions whether if it's recurring or nonrecurring. So we'd just rather keep it in core and identi
componenttext: Thanks, Ron. On the broader question of core versus noncore, given the size of this, there's a number of items that we have during any year where there are questions whether if it's recurring or nonrecurring. So we'd just rather keep it in core and identified. If it's large, discrete or if you sell a business or we shut down some, those things are clearly in our view, noncore. These ones are, I think we prefer to keep them in core and identify them as such.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is Ted. I'm going to pick up from here. Obviously, you know this is my last earnings call with Edison and just aske you to indulge me while I make a few closing comments. First, it has been a true honor to be the CEO of Edison international. Th
componenttext:
Okay. This is Ted. I'm going to pick up from here. Obviously, you know this is my last earnings call with Edison and just aske you to indulge me while I make a few closing comments. First, it has been a true honor to be the CEO of Edison international. This company has been an essential part of the economic fabric of this region for 130 years, during which we provided the most essential of goods for modern society to function and prosper, that is electricity. Being a part of this great company is truly humbling. I'm exceptionally proud of what this management team and our employees have accomplished these last years. I'm sincerely grateful for the wisdom, advice, counsel of our Board of Directors that they've provided. I particularly want to single out Jim Scilacci, just because it's so much fun, for a huge thank you. He, above all, will tell me like it is. Tell me what I must hear, not what I might like to hear. And he does it with such glee. He's been a great friend and a great colleague. So thanks, Jim. I believe we have crafted a strong strategy for success and value creation here at Edison. We have overcome many obstacles. You might say we're still getting our training leg over a couple of hurdles. We have repositioned SCE to be a wires-focused electric utility, in-sync with and essential to California's low-carbon policy objectives. Edison Energy has the potential to create a new business model, concentrating mostly on commercial and industrial customers and grid edge customer-focused energy services. We continue to gain confidence that both Edison Energy and SCE are pioneers in their respective business. We may even look back one day and conclude that both were disrupters of a sort. 
I'm unabashedly bullish on this company's strategy and its prospects. But a good strategy doesn't stand alone. It must have exceptional execution and leadership to be successful, and that is why I am so excited by the new leadership team who will be taking the reins in a couple of months. 
In my opinion, Pedro is an exceptional leader. He understands our business and our industry well, and has the skills, the attitude and the discipline to navigate our complex environment. I look forward to Pedro, along with Kevin Payne and Ron Nichols at SCE; Ron Litzinger at Edison Energy; Maria Rigatti as the CFO; and the rest of the senior leadership team taking this great company to the next level of performance. I'm confident that they can. 
Finally, it has been a real pleasure working with many of you as investors in Edison International. We have many stakeholders in this business, but investors are certainly one of the most important. We provide society with an essential service. But none of our investment and critical infrastructure is possible without the capital that you provide. I hope you feel we have rewarded your faith and confidence in us with superior performance and attractive returns. 
I will speak for Jim and myself here by saying we look forward to participating in future earnings calls as interested parties and investors, but in listen-only mode. So many thanks to all of you, both around this table here as well as you on the phone. 
And with that, Scott, you want to wrap this up?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Edison International Second Quarter 2016 Financial Teleconference. My name is Tony, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Scott Cunningham, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Cunningham, you may begin your conference.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Welcome, everyone. Our principal speakers today will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here are other members of the management team.Materials
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Welcome, everyone. Our principal speakers today will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ted Craver; and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Jim Scilacci. Also here are other members of the management team.
Materials supporting today's call are available at www.edisoninvestor.com. These include our Form 10-Q, Ted's and Jim's prepared remarks, and the presentation that accompanies Jim's comments. Tomorrow afternoon, we will distribute our regular business update presentation. 
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements about the future outlook for Edison International and its subsidiaries. Actual results could differ materially from current expectations. Important factors that could cause different results are set forth in our SEC filings. Please read these carefully. Presentation includes certain outlook assumptions as well as reconciliation of GAAP and non-GAAP measures. [Operator Instructions] 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Ted.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Second quarter results were below last year's results as we expected. You will recall that we told investors in our first quarter earnings call that quarterly year-over-year comparisons would not be all that
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Second quarter results were below last year's results as we expected. You will recall that we told investors in our first quarter earnings call that quarterly year-over-year comparisons would not be all that meaningful. This is primarily due to timing mismatches, including: impacts from the delayed decision on SCE's 2015 to '17 rate case; significant SCE tax benefits recorded last year, but not repeated this year; no Edison capital asset sales this year versus last year; and the timing of Edison Energy costs versus revenues.
The larger point that I want to leave with you is that core earnings are on track for the full year. That is why today we reaffirmed our full year core earnings guidance range of $3.81 to $4.01 earnings per share. In fact, based on second quarter results, although there are various puts and takes amongst the businesses, our current outlook indicates that consolidated results for the full year are in the top half of our guidance range. However, consistent with what we have done in several of the past years, we will hold off until our third quarter results are in to decide if we should adjust our core earnings guidance. 
We are in the final half of our 2015 to '17 CPUC rate case period. We have communicated to investors that based on CPUC-approved capital spending and expected spending on FERC jurisdictional transmission projects, we expect rate base growth -- rate base to grow approximately 7% in the 2016 to '17 period. This still seems appropriate. We have communicated several times in the past that there is relatively little variance expected in the timing of CPUC jurisdictional spending for the 2016 to '17 period, but more variability is possible in the timing, but less likely in the ultimate amount of our FERC jurisdictional transmission spending. Remember, SCE's transmission investment is to improve system reliability and bring online utility scale wind and solar resources to meet California's aggressive renewable energy targets. Most of the transmission CapEx spending variability occurs due to delays in routing decisions and permitting approvals at the state and federal levels. A recent example was the $1.1 billion West of Devers project, which has been something of a moving target with CPUC staff even with CAISO support, but appears ready for final CPUC approval with a supportive alternate proposed decision pending.
We see scheduled challenges of this sort for other lesser transmission projects as well. Net-net, we don't expect meaningful impacts to our total transmission spend expectations over the medium-term 3- to 5-year period, but likely some shifting between the years. Said differently, our current view is that 2016 rate base will not be materially different than forecasted. 2017 could be slightly lower, but recovered in the 2018 to 2020 period. 
On the last earnings call, most of my comments were devoted to outlining the future SCE growth opportunity. I'd like to provide some additional comments today, keeping in mind that we will be able to elaborate more on this when SCE makes its General Rate Case filing on September 1. 
In the broadest sense, the capital spending request in our 2018 to 2020 General Rate Case is designed to help California achieve its low carbon policy objectives and to enable customer choice, while continuing to focus on reliable and affordable service for all customers. Keeping it simple, the requested investment can be lumped into 2 buckets. The first bucket is comprised of grid investments we have traditionally requested in the past rate cases. The second bucket is made up of new grid modernization investments. Let me expand further on these 2 areas. 
The traditional investments we will propose in the first bucket represent the vast majority of our total rate case capital spending request. The areas of spending encompass 5 basic elements: replacement of aging infrastructure; new customer connections and demand growth on certain circuits; investments in information technology to improve customer service and cost efficiency; maintenance capital spending on SCE's generation fleet; and other core investments such as in our operations facilities.
This first bucket of requested spending, together with other non-GRC spending, such as SCE's electric vehicle charging program and FERC transmission spending, is expected to total more than $4 billion in CapEx per year. It is difficult to handicap how much of our requested investment in this first bucket of capital spending will ultimately be approved. However, investors have some history to observe in this regard. SCE received 81% of its requested capital spending in the 2009 to '11 General Rate Case, 89% of its 2012 to '14 General Rate Case request, and 92% of its 2015 to '17 request. 
The smaller second bucket of spending we will request is new. It is for modernization of the distribution system and is part of SCE's strategy to facilitate the growth of distributed energy resources. Governor Brown and the California legislature have stated their strong desire for California to lead the nation in developing policies to create a low carbon economy, while creating jobs and prosperity for its citizens. SB 350, signed into law last year, stated the goal of making the electric grid a key enabler of California's low carbon policy ambitions, including by electrifying transportation. The CPUC has 2 active proceedings underway, which together will help shape the long-term planning for this vision. 
From a capital investment perspective, the most important is the distribution resources plan proceeding. In this proceeding, the CPUC's stated goal is to modernize the distribution system during the next decade, but it provided only some early direction on preferred technologies and required investments.
SCE, through its 2018 to 2020 General Rate Case, will be the first electric utility to provide specificity for how this technology evolution should unfold. This will be the new element of our September 1 filing. We need to wait until that filing to be specific about the amount and details of our investment request, but you should expect that the overall level of the request will be roughly consistent with our DRP filing last summer. At this time, based on the pace of grid modernization that SCE will describe in its 2018 GRC filing, it is expected that grid modernization capital expenditures and rate base growth will continue beyond 2025. 
Some of the requested grid modernization investment would be better characterized as reinforcing the existing system, such as upgrading low voltage circuits in order to accommodate higher penetration of distributed energy resources. But other parts really have no precedent, and therefore, we do not know how to handicap how much of our request might finally be approved. 
Like any technology evolution, there are certain initial investments that need to be made to create the foundational infrastructure that will support system-wide grid modernization. SCE has identified the critical path that it believes needs to get started sooner rather than later. That has what led SCE to file on July 13 for a memorandum account, requesting authority from the CPUC to track certain early-stage investment cost ahead of its 2018 General Rate Case filing. The July 13 request points out that the process of modernizing the distribution grid requires some near-term planning, engineering, procurement and installation of certain distribution system upgrades before the 2018 SCE-GRC period. SCE's July 13 filing requests authority to track the revenue requirement of approximately $100 million of capital spending to be placed in service in 2017, that is critical to meeting the CPUC's overall time line for grid modernization. If the memorandum account is approved and expenditures are deemed prudent, the associated rate base will be included in either the 2018 or perhaps the 2021 General Rate Case filing.
I'll finish with comments on 2 other matters. The first is SONGS. Last week we, and other parties, completed briefings requested by the CPUC. The court question was whether the SONGS settlement, unanimously approved by the CPUC, was still reasonable given the various disclosures about ex-parte communications made last year. There were 6 signatories to the SONGS settlement. 4 of the 6 settling parties, San Diego Gas & Electric, Friends of the Earth, The Coalition of California Utility Employees and SCE, submitted filings that made clear why these communications had no impact on the settlement process and why the settlement remains reasonable, lawful and in the public interest. Two of the settling parties turned an ORA are seeking in their filings to impose additional penalties on SCE. We strongly believe this is opportunistic and inappropriate. We also note that before approving the settlement, the commission asked the settling parties to amend the settlement in meaningful ways, all of which were more favorable for customers, which the parties ultimately did. The commission then unanimously approved that amended settlement. 
While there remains no time line for further action, we are hopeful that the commission will see the record as demonstrating the validity and appropriateness of the settlement by reaffirming the settlement and dismissing the pending appeals. 
The final item is the important CPUC reforms announced in late June by the governor and key legislators, and subsequently, endorsed by the CPUC. These reforms largely address a series of principles the governor has advocated, while balancing sensitivities over the role of the executive and legislative branches in designing and implementing these reforms. While there are many details yet to be finalized, the overall approach appears responsive. If implemented as described, it should continue to provide broad public access to the decision-making process, accelerate timely decision-making, address important CPUC staffing and recruiting issues and allow CPUC commissioners more leeway to discuss important topics amongst themselves. 
This concludes my remarks. Jim will now provide his financial update.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ted, and hello, everyone. My comments today will cover second quarter and year-to-date results, earnings guidance and our updated capital expenditures and rate base forecasts. Please turn to Page 2 of the presentation.As a brief reminder, compar
componenttext:
Thanks, Ted, and hello, everyone. My comments today will cover second quarter and year-to-date results, earnings guidance and our updated capital expenditures and rate base forecasts. Please turn to Page 2 of the presentation.
As a brief reminder, comparisons to 2015 will not be meaningful, primarily because of the timing of the 2015 GRC decision and the impact of taxes. I also explained last quarter how we removed, in a variance analysis, the impact of repair deductions, pole loading and San Onofre tax items because these revenue items have offsets within the income statement. 
EIX' basic and core earnings per share are $0.85 for the second quarter or $0.31 per share less than the same quarter last year. SCE's second quarter basic and core earnings are $0.21 per share lower and EIX Parent and Other are $0.10 per share lower. The lower earnings are primarily due to $0.31 per share of income tax benefits recorded in the second quarter of last year. 
Focusing on the SCE key EPS drivers column, the utilities revenue was $0.10 per share higher quarter-over-quarter. This increase includes $0.09 per share from a GRC attrition mechanism, which automatically adjusts authorized revenue following the 2015 test year. This is largely offset by a $0.06 per share timing issue with the 2015 GRC decision. As I discussed last quarter, authorized revenue reductions from the 2015 GRC decision are not reflected in results for the first or second quarter of this year. You'll see this reverse in the third and fourth quarters of this year. There is also a $0.03 per share positive variance from the pole loading balancing account. This balancing account was created with the final 2015 GRC decision, so the $0.08 of pole loading earnings we had last year were all -- was all recorded in the fourth quarter. FERC revenues are $0.03 per share higher. This is largely related to revenues associated with the higher operating costs and abandoned plant recoveries for the canceled Coolwater-Lugo transmission project. The recovery of Coolwater-Lugo cost will continue through 2016 and has no impact on earnings. Together, these revenue items net to a positive $0.10 per share. 
O&M was not a major driver in the second quarter as lower legal and labor costs, due to workforce reductions, are mostly offset by a planned outage and upgrades at the Mountainview Generation Plant and higher pole loading costs. Results included $0.02 per share of severance costs comparable to what was recorded last year. $0.03 of the $0.04 of higher depreciation are amortization of the Coolwater-Lugo cost discussed above. 
Net financing costs are $0.02 per share higher, due primarily to an increase in the amount of preferred stock outstanding. The CPUC and FERC rate [indiscernible] include funding for new debt and preferred stock to finance rate base growth. As indicated above, there was a $0.31 per share benefit from a change in an uncertain tax positions in 2015. There is no comparable change in the second quarter of this year. Partially offsetting this item is a $0.04 per share benefit this year from tax depreciation and balancing accounts, bringing the net impact from income taxes to a negative $0.27.
The second quarter effective tax rate for SCE is a negative 9%, due primarily to a $133 million flow-through tax refund to customers for repair benefits from 2012 through 2014. The refunded tax repair benefits has no earnings impact. 
Higher insurance benefits primarily drive the $0.02 per share contribution from other income and expenses. This gets us to the $0.21 per share decline in the second quarter SCE earnings.
I will turn next to EIX Parent and Other. Losses increased by $0.10 per share overall from last quarter -- last quarter of last year. A key driver is a $0.04 per share buyout of an earn-out provision with former shareholders and their current employees of a company acquired by Edison Energy at the end of 2015. The buyout was completed along with modification of employment contracts to align Edison Energy's incentive compensation with EIX'. There is also a $0.01 per share of higher business development and operating costs. Comparisons are also affected by a $0.03 per share gain on the sale of a portion of Edison Capital's affordable housing portfolio during the second quarter of last year. 
Parent holding company costs increased by $0.02 per share due to higher interest expense as we termed out $400 million of holding company commercial paper debt and the impact of strong stock price performance on compensation expense. Core earnings exclude a $0.01 per share of tax-related losses and discontinued operations related to the Edison Mission Energy getting to the net $0.10 per share of holding company losses. That, with the SCE variance, gets you to the $0.31 per share reduction in EIX earnings. 
Please turn to Page 3. I won't go into detail on the year-to-date results, other than to remind everyone that SCE's performance for the first half of 2016 is consistent with our full year SCE outlook, which look stronger than our original guidance levels. At the same time, holding company costs are already at full year guidance levels or $0.18 per share. We've built both factors into our reaffirmed full year guidance. 
Please turn to Page 4. On the top of this slide, it shows our reaffirmed GAAP and core earnings guidance. However, our internal SCE earnings outlook will be above its $4.09 per share guidance midpoint, and holding company costs outlook will be higher than its guidance midpoint. We're comfortable reaffirming overall EIX earnings guidance for the full year based on this internal view. However, we have not updated our SCE and holding company guidance elements other than to indicate their directional trends. We are mindful that the third quarter is typically SCE's strongest of the year, and we will continue our practice of looking to update guidance when we report third quarter results on November 1. 
As I previously mentioned, holding company year-to-date costs, including Edison Energy Group, are at a full year guidance level of $0.14 -- excuse me, at $0.18. Adjusting for an earn-out agreement, which was not part of the original guidance, was lower year-to-date cost of $0.14. The important thing is that we do anticipate an increase in revenue during the second half of 2016 based on booked deals and expected sales. I also want to point out that our guidance does not include any recoveries from the MHI arbitration. As a reminder, we are expensing all costs related to the arbitration as incurred through core earnings. For 2016 alone, we incurred $23 million of costs and a total of $76 million, including prior periods. As part of the SONGS settlement, we can recover our reasonable arbitration cost from MHI recoveries before sharing.
I will next touch on SCE's balance sheet strength. On June 30, SCE's weighted average common equity ratio was 50.3% versus the authorized level of 48%. This helps provide financial flexibility as the utility continues to fund growth with operating cash flow and retain earnings and without the need of new common equity. 
Please turn to Page 5. SCE has updated its capital spending forecast. We expect that 2016 will be lower by $300 million, and '17 will be $100 million higher. The biggest factor change -- forecast change is $375 million of transmission spending, mostly due to licensing delays of projects like Alberhill, Mesa and the City of Riverside projects. As Ted has highlighted, we firmly believe these projects will ultimately move forward, and the balance of their capital spending will be shifted into our 2018 through '20 period.
We have also adjusted the utility's CPUC capital expenditures to more closely align with what the commission has authorized for the 3-year General Rate Case cycle. The net result of these changes is a reduction of approximately $200 million. 
Please turn to Page 6. You'll see that rate base has a directionally similar adjustment with the 2017 rate base forecast to be lower by $200 million. Because of the transmission delays, the reduction in rate base will be shifted into the 2018 through '20 period. As I mentioned earlier, we don't see this having any impact on 2016 earnings, as the modest rate base reduction has more than offset in other areas based on SCE's current outlook.
I would like to add a short addendum to my prepared remarks. This earnings call is my 32nd and last CFO of EIX. It's been a great 8-year run. There's a lot of work that goes into each one of these calls and I'd like to recognize our Edison team that makes these calls happen. Personally, I think our disclosures and investment materials are among the best. This job falls to our lawyers, accountants, corporate communications folks and IR staff. In particular, our attorneys, Adams -- Adam, Russ, Barbara, Kathleen, do a great job of converting accounting English into plain English. Our accountants, Aaron, Connie, Mark and Trisha make sure our books and SEC filings are in top shape. Our IR staff, Scott and Ally, do a fantastic job. As many of you know, Scott is a highly regarded IR professional and Ally has done a great job since joining us a year ago. 
I have always enjoyed the interaction with investors and analysts over the years. Hopefully, you have earned our respect by the way we conduct our communications. Early on, Ted advised me, when communicating with investors and analysts, I should strive to keep my comments down at middle of the fairway. Ted said if I push my comments left or right of center, you folks will sniff it out and our credibility will be called into question. I have tried to follow this solid advice, and I hope Pedro and Maria do the same. 
As you know, Ted and I are heading out on September 30. I don't have any plans for retirement yet, but there are many things that I want to do. The one thing I would really like to do, though, is finally learn how to drive my golf balls down the middle of the fairway. 
Thank you, all. Operator, it's question time.

I suppose it's someone awkward given the timing, can you pine a little bit on the desirability of the utilities and the utility jurisdictions outside of California? I mean, to what extent is there, given the media headlines a desire to expand? Or deviate from the Edison Energy strategy you guys have previously articulated as being the go-forward plan outside of SCE?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Ted. I'll weight into that SCE question. I think we've been fairly open with investors over the years about our prospects and, in a weird way, the most difficult element is we have tremendous growth prospects here at Southern California, E
componenttext: Julien, this is Ted. I'll weight into that SCE question. I think we've been fairly open with investors over the years about our prospects and, in a weird way, the most difficult element is we have tremendous growth prospects here at Southern California, Edison. So our organic growth and the expected CAGRs from rate base and ultimately earnings really make looking at other utilities outside of our territory as more often than not looking dilutive, either to the underlying strategic approach that we have, which is, as you know, a wires-based focus or a delivery of electricity focus, rather than a heavy involvement in some of the other parts of the business, or dilutive from an earnings growth perspective. So as a result of that, we've continued to focus primarily on where we see the best opportunities, and those are really our organic growth opportunities. I'd like to keep it at the 100,000-foot level. I certainly don't want to engage in speculation on any specific thing.

componenttext: Okay, okay. And then to get to the higher end of the range for the year, given that the parent drag will be higher, again, would imply that you would be earning above your authorized ROE for this final year in this GRC. How much sort of capacity do you have to further cut back on cost so you can continue to do that in the 3-year cycle of the GRC program? Which innings are we, as far as the cost reductions cycle is concerned?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's an ongoing process. I think when we started this 4 years ago, there was a lot to be done. And if you just look at our headcount, there's been a lot of reductions over the last 4 years, compliments to Ron Litzinger and the effort he started and contin
componenttext: It's an ongoing process. I think when we started this 4 years ago, there was a lot to be done. And if you just look at our headcount, there's been a lot of reductions over the last 4 years, compliments to Ron Litzinger and the effort he started and continue with Pedro. And there's more to be done. And what we keep fighting when we do these benchmarking studies, those in the first quartile keep getting more competitive. They continue to reduce their cost. So the job for us is they're even greater to keep up with them and then they're closing the ranks, because our goal here is to get to first quartile. So there's more to be done. And we've indicated it in our guidance for this year and we've indicated there will be some earnings from cost reductions next year's, too. And of course, we passed that back as part of that 2018 GRC and then we started fresh looking for cost reductions.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask a little bit of a question kind of thinking about long-term capital spending levels. I mean, Ted, in your prepared remarks, are you implying that you think some of the capital spending levels will remain in the low $4 billion a year ran
componenttext: I just want to ask a little bit of a question kind of thinking about long-term capital spending levels. I mean, Ted, in your prepared remarks, are you implying that you think some of the capital spending levels will remain in the low $4 billion a year range, or do you think it's when you make your 2018 rate case filing and get into the DRP filing and docket that we're talking about something that's materially different from that level?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll maybe some slightly different words but capture the same themes. What I was really trying to do in the prepared remarks is say just kind of keeping this thing simple. You should expect in our 2018 general rate case to see expenses kind of in two
componenttext: Yes, I'll maybe some slightly different words but capture the same themes. What I was really trying to do in the prepared remarks is say just kind of keeping this thing simple. You should expect in our 2018 general rate case to see expenses kind of in two very broad buckets. One bucket is what I call pretty much traditional meat and potato type investment request that we make every general rate case. So that covers kind of standard stuff, infrastructure replacement, expected demand, increases on certain of our circuits, new connections, so on and so forth. When you take that chunk together with the things that aren't in the GRC, such as the Charge Ready program and FERC jurisdictional transmission spend, you should expect to see a number, generally in the neighborhood, maybe a little bit higher than what we have traditionally kind of talked about. So I'll just call that broadly the $4-billion-plus type of base number. Then there's the second smaller bucket that you will see in the 2018 general rate case request, which will really going to be the first attempt to try to put some specificity around what is required to really modernize the distribution system, such that it can facilitate the state's carbon reduction goals and customer choice on technology. So distributed energy resources. And that's a lot harder for us at this early juncture to be able to handicap, one of that would ultimately be approved. So there's kind of the standard stuff, which when you lump it together with transmission spending and the like, it's going to look pretty similar to what you've seen in the past from us, maybe a little bit higher. And then there's a new layer of stuff that, really, this rate case will kind of start that conversation about what that might look like. And that would be additive to that kind of base level. So this is what I signaled last earnings call and what we've elaborated on a little bit more in this earnings call.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you talk to customer groups and when you meet with some of the big parties, how flexible are they in terms of the balance need to modernize the distribution system versus the impact of what that does on rates and therefore their own economics?
componenttext: And when you talk to customer groups and when you meet with some of the big parties, how flexible are they in terms of the balance need to modernize the distribution system versus the impact of what that does on rates and therefore their own economics?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in a nut -- I didn't go into it again here on this call, but last earnings call, I made a fairly evolved discussion about what has been the pace of electric rate increases relative to the pace of underlying consumer price index increases. And if you
componenttext: Yes, in a nut -- I didn't go into it again here on this call, but last earnings call, I made a fairly evolved discussion about what has been the pace of electric rate increases relative to the pace of underlying consumer price index increases. And if you -- a lot of this depends on what you're starting with and what you are ending with. But as I said in the last call, whether you looked at the 1-year, the 5-year, the 10, the 20, the rate of increase in customer rates, the system average rate, has actually been at or below the rate of inflation, the Southern California area CPI. I think I remember the 20 year number because that's kind of the probably the most relevant one. So over the long-term, that CPI increase, from '95 to '15, was 2.4% compound annual growth rate. The rate of increase in electric rates over that same '95 to '15 period was 2.0% CAGR, compound annual growth rate. So as it kind of demonstrates over the long haul, we've been able to manage the price of electricity at or below the rate of inflation and that continues to be kind of our overall goal. Now you have periods where you get more of a surge and you get other periods where you end up consolidating some of those increases. But the key, I think, over the long haul is to have the price of electricity stay at or below the rate of inflation. That's our overall goal. That remains our goal.

componenttext: This is Ted. I'll just do something really quick here. I think most of the focus most recently has been on SoCore. So that's our solar -- distributed solar generation company, and Edison Energy, which is the new venture that's focused on providing energy services to commercial and industrial customers. I think at this juncture, we may have made some comment about this at the -- in the last earnings call. But I think we feel encouraged based on customer reaction to the launch of Edison Energy, the C&I energy services business. But this isn't one of those things where it's going to get built overnight. This is going to take some time. It really isn't, as we see it at least, there isn't a category out there that addresses the market that we're trying to create. So it's going to take a little bit of time. But we're encouraged based on customer reaction and we're encouraged based on some deals that have been coming in the door the last few months. So I'll just kind of leave it there. I don't think you should expect we'll be providing something every quarter on this. It's probably more likely to be maybe a couple of times a year as this thing progresses.

componenttext: Pedro?

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Pedro Pizarro. I would also add that I would expect that the kind of spending that we see over the next few years is all going to be fairly foundational. So -- and we'll provide more detail on that in the GRC. But even in what we put out ther
componenttext: Yes, this is Pedro Pizarro. I would also add that I would expect that the kind of spending that we see over the next few years is all going to be fairly foundational. So -- and we'll provide more detail on that in the GRC. But even in what we put out there in our DRP filing last year and the materials that Jim was referencing earlier in our business update, if you take a look at the categories of spend there, I think those are fairly foundational. It's upgrading circuits, some of our older circuits that are lower voltage, they need to be brought up to more modern standards in order to accommodate distributed energy resources. And then it's also technology side things around our field area network, the communications infrastructure to having enough bandwidth to handle the new devices out there. So I think that, that would hopefully provide some little narrower range in terms of the direction. But you're right to the extent that priorities change through DRP or the policy filings that ultimately gets reflected in the GRCs.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, related to this and Ted mentioned in his comments, is the memorandum account that we just recently filed. And we want to spend some capital and O&M dollars especially next year. It's really hard to step up in a material way to ramp-up a program and
componenttext: Mike, related to this and Ted mentioned in his comments, is the memorandum account that we just recently filed. And we want to spend some capital and O&M dollars especially next year. It's really hard to step up in a material way to ramp-up a program and you need to do it in steps. And that's what that memorandum account is really designed to do, to get us going and then give us a running start into the '18 GRC period. So that's an important milestone in what the commission does with that will be an important thing for our GRC.

componenttext: Really, it was to make sure that all the acquired companies are incentivized around the earnings or the EBITDA for the entire Edison Energy enterprise. And when we did the acquisitions, we did not have a long-term incentive plan established. We now have that debt based on Edison Energy earnings in total and we felt it was best where there were individual earnouts that were aligned around goals of the earnings for that entity only did not line up with our broader integrated and cross-selling model. And so we felt it best to transition everyone to the Edison Energy long-term incentive program and get out of the earnout.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
