componenttext: Thanks, Ron. On the broader question of core versus noncore, given the size of this, there's a number of items that we have in any -- during any year where there are questions whether if it's recurring or nonrecurring. So we'd just rather keep it in core and identify it. If it's large, discrete or if you sell a business or when we shut down some, those things are clearly in our view, noncore. These ones are, I think we just prefer to keep them in core and identify them as such.

headline: Edison International, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, it's Ted, and I'm going to kind of pick up from here. Obviously, you know this is my last earnings call with Edison and just ask you to indulge me while I make a few closing comments. First, it is been a true honor to be the CEO of Edison in
componenttext:
Okay. Well, it's Ted, and I'm going to kind of pick up from here. Obviously, you know this is my last earnings call with Edison and just ask you to indulge me while I make a few closing comments. 
First, it is been a true honor to be the CEO of Edison international. This company has been an essential part of the economic fabric of this region for 130 years, during which we've provided the most essential of goods for modern society to function and prosper, that is, electricity. To have been a part of this great company is truly humbling. I'm exceptionally proud of what this management team and our employees have accomplished these last years. I'm sincerely grateful for the wisdom, advice, counsel of our Board of Directors that they've provided. I particularly want to single out Jim Scilacci, just cause it's so much fun, for a huge thank you. He, above all, will tell me like it is. Tell me what I must hear, not what I might like to hear. And he does it with such glee. He's been a great friend and a great colleague. So thank you, Jim. I believe we have crafted a strong strategy for success and value creation here at Edison. We have overcome many obstacles. You might say we're still getting our trailing leg over a couple of hurdles yet. We have repositioned SCE to be a wires-focused electric utility, in sync with and essential to California's low carbon policy objectives. Edison Energy has the potential to create a new business model, concentrating mostly on commercial and industrial customers and grid edge customer-focused energy services. We continue to gain confidence that both Edison Energy and SCE are pioneers in their respective business. We may even look back one day and conclude that both were disrupters of a sort.
I'm unabashedly bullish on this company's strategy and its prospects. But a good strategy doesn't stand alone. It must have exceptional execution and leadership to be successful, and that is why I am so excited by the new leadership team who will be taking the reins in a couple of months. 
In my opinion, Pedro is an exceptional leader. He understands our business and our industry well, and has the skills, the attitude and the discipline to navigate our complex environment. I look forward to Pedro, along with Kevin Payne and Ron Nichols at SCE; Ron Litzinger at Edison Energy; Maria Rigatti as the CFO; and the rest of the senior leadership team taking this great company to the next level of performance. I'm confident that they can.
Finally, it has been a real pleasure working with many of you as investors in Edison International. We have many stakeholders in this business, but investors are certainly one of the most important. We provide society with an essential service. But none of our investment and critical infrastructure is possible without the capital that you provide. I hope you feel we have rewarded your faith and confidence in us with superior performance and attractive returns.
I will speak for Jim and myself here by saying we look forward to participating in future earnings calls as interested parties and investors but in listen-only mode. So many thanks to all of you, both around this table here as well as you on the phone.
And with that, Scott, you want to wrap this up?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Christy, and welcome to everyone. Our speakers today are President, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Pedro Pizarro; and Chief Financial Officer, Maria Rigatti. Also here are other members of the management team. Materials supporting today's c
componenttext: Thanks, Christy, and welcome to everyone. Our speakers today are President, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Pedro Pizarro; and Chief Financial Officer, Maria Rigatti. Also here are other members of the management team. Materials supporting today's call are available at www.edison.com. These include our Form 10-Q, Pedro's and Maria's prepared remarks, and the teleconference presentation. Tomorrow afternoon, we'll distribute our regular business update. During this call, we will make forward-looking statements about the future outlook for Edison International and its subsidiaries. Actual results could differ materially from current expectations. Important factors that could cause different results are set forth in our SEC filings. Please read these carefully. The Presentation includes certain outlook assumptions as well as reconciliation of GAAP and non-GAAP measures. to the nearest GAAP measure. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Pedro.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. I am excited and also humbled to be here on this first earnings call with Maria in our new roles. I want to thank [indiscernible] and Jim for all of their help in our transition over the summer. I also thank
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. I am excited and also humbled to be here on this first earnings call with Maria in our new roles. I want to thank [indiscernible] and Jim for all of their help in our transition over the summer. I also thank many of you whom Ted and I had an opportunity to visit in September. While the main purpose of our visits was to share our key messages on continuity of leadership and continuity of strategy, I believe I benefited the most from the visits as the dialogue helped me a great deal. I look forward to our continued discussion, and our team will strive hard to maintain our commitment to transparency and full engagement with our investors. 
In today's call, Maria will cover the financial results, so I will focus on the recent strategic developments at SCE and in California that will help shape Edison International's long-term growth.
I'll start with SCE's 2018 General Rate Case filed September 1. This filing demonstrates SCE's commitment to 3 key strategy elements: First, maintain a safe and reliable wireless network; second, be a key enabler of California's commitment to addressing climate change through significant greenhouse gas reduction led by our proposed grid modernization efforts to support widespread adoption of solar, storage, electric vehicle charging and other technologies; and finally, continue our operational excellence journey to achieve top quartile performance in safety, reliability, customer satisfaction and costs. We believe we have made a strong case for our strategy and for the requested funding level in our rate case filing. Recently, CPUC President, Picker [ph] and 2 administrative law judges were assigned to the case. President Ficker is also leading the broader proceeding looking at distribution resource plans which is addressing many of the policy and technical details of solar and other distributed energy resources. Having the same commissioner overseeing these 2 highly inter related proceedings should prove very constructive. We are also hopeful that the comments President Ficker made at the CPUC's June 23 meeting regarding the need for timelier General Rate Case decisions will set the tone for SCE's rate case. We will look to do our part.
Based on past practice, we should receive a proposed schedule shortly. Last week SCE held its first of several GRC workshops which was well attended, including by both the assigned ALJs. We had lots of good questions and comments their various parties regarding both traditional GRC elements as well as SCE's grid modernization proposals. The grid modernization efforts included in the GRC request will support California's implementation of Senate Bill 32 signed by Governor Brown in September 8. This legislation requires the states to cut greenhouse gas emissions 40% below 1990 levels by 2030 in order to help address global climate change. California has led the way over the past decades with progressive policies across renewables, energy efficiency, vehicle fuel standards and cap and trade. According to the California air resources Board's more recent report using 2014 data, these actions have all helped California achieve greenhouse gas emissions that are only 3% higher than 1990 levels, over a time period when California's population grew 30%. Keeping greenhouse gas emissions roughly constant over 24 years of population and economic growth was a remarkable achievement, thanks to the very hard work, yet our state is now legally committed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions 42% from current levels by 2030. That is only 14 years from now. 
Grid modernization, which by the CPUC's estimate, will be an ongoing effort into the middle part of the next decade, is a very significant part of the needed solution. We believe that California will have to move much more aggressively and sooner rather than later to meet these new legislative mandates within a short 14 years. Many of California's policies to date had focused on electric power, but generation, both in-state and from imports, represents only an estimated 20% of current statewide greenhouse gas emissions. The largest source of greenhouse gas emissions is the transportation sector with an estimated 36% of current emissions. Industrial sources represent another 21%. We believe that significant new efforts across all sectors of the economy will be needed, and many of these efforts will require significant electrification of sectors that today rely on fossil fuels. We see ourselves as a key partner with California in this effort. 
Edison International is committed to being one of the most constructive agents of change in helping California meet its greenhouse gas objectives. I plan on talking in more detail in how to do this in my November 8 remarks at the Edison Electric Institute Financial Conference. 
Let me next anticipate your questions on 2 topics we're asked about regularly; namely, the status of the songs settlement and the MHI arbitration. SCE continuos to implement the settlement. We have reduced rates and refunded or will refund nearly $1.6 billion under the terms of the settlement. With respect to the pending appeals of the settlement decision, we can't predict when the CPUC will act. We continue to believe the settlement is lawful, fair and in the best interest of our customers. With respect to MHI, we remain hopeful that we will receive a decision later this year or early next year. Once we receive a decision from the International Chamber of Commerce panel, we will promptly disclose its key findings. In the spirit of transparency, SCE plans to make the actual decision public as soon as possible, though this will require agreement with MHI on what proprietary information must be kept confidential. 
Should the arbitration outcome be favorable to the song's owners, SCE will refund to customers under the SONGS settlement 50% of any proceeds that exceed legal expenses. SCE expects is its share of any recoveries the paid down or reduce the use of short-term debt needed to help finance SCE's capital spending program. 
I also want to comment on the CPUC proceeding examining the SCE customer outages in Long Beach in July 2015. You may recall that we had multiple underground volt fires and underground failures, which affected much of the downtown area and adjoining neighborhoods. The problem centered in a unique portion of SCE's distribution system that is arranged in a network configuration similar to those used in dense urban areas like Manhattan. Most of our systems has a radial design instead. 
SCE has made a number of changes in our systems and management processes as a result of these outages. The CPUC proceeding will determine if fines are warranted and proposed penalty amounts which could be significant but we are not able to estimate this at this early stage of the proceeding. Hearings are first scheduled for February of next year.
Turning briefly to our new business activities. We continue to develop energy advisory services and solutions for large commercial and industrial customers, which Edison Energy launched in March. Customer feedback has been quite encouraging, and our customers include a number of Fortune 1000 companies and a dozen of the Fortune 50. That said, we still have much work to do to flesh out a compelling value proposition that will grow this into a profitable business with meaningful scale.
We expect to complete evolving our initial business case into a detailed business plan with importantly, near-term milestones that our board, management and our investors can use to measure our progress. I expect this to be able to provide you this detail no later than the next 12 months. 
We are continuing to refine the scope and strategy for all our competitive business initiatives. We will concentrate on those that will give us the best opportunities to capture additional value and scale from the technology changes that are transforming the nature of our industry. Our focus is on a capital light business model that maximizes the opportunity for value creation and complements our core SCE utility business. At the same time, the cost to develop these businesses continue. While we have reaffirmed our 2016 earnings guidance, we expect to bound the costs of new business development for Edison Energy and provide additional detail in our guidance for 2017. I am committed to implementing our Edison Energy Group strategies at a pace that creates opportunities for meaningful growth, yet is disciplined and does not detract from Edison International's opportunity to deliver above industry earnings and dividend growth and resulting value for investors. 
I'll finish up with one last example of management continuity. A continued dividend growth opportunity in steps and overtime to continue our well-known phrase from prior earnings calls. Today, we are only of the low end of our target payout range of 45% to 55% of SCE earnings based on the midpoint of our earnings guidance. We want to continue to move well into the range, which means a dividend growth opportunity higher than our earnings growth. With the engagement and support of our employees, I expect we'll do great things together for our customers and our shareholders. 
With that, let me turn things over to Maria.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pedro. It is a privilege and honor to be here, and I look forward to working with everyone in my new role. Now let's review the numbers. The plan on following a format similar to what we've been using in prior earnings calls, commenting on the fin
componenttext:
Thanks, Pedro. It is a privilege and honor to be here, and I look forward to working with everyone in my new role. Now let's review the numbers. The plan on following a format similar to what we've been using in prior earnings calls, commenting on the financial results, our updated guidance, our capital plan and a few other financial topics. I will try not to repeat the numbers you can see on the presentation, but rather focus on the underlying trends and explanation. 
Please turn to Page 2 of the presentation. As discussed in our prior investor call this, year quarterly earnings comparisons are awkward due to the timing of last year's rate case decision. SCE reflected the proposed decision in the third quarter of last year. At that time, SCE recorded most, but not all of the expected impacts of our proposed decision. Some of last year's third quarter impacts related to the first half of 2015, so the third quarter comparisons are not perfectly aligned. Comparisons to the prior year are clearer in the year-to-date information. Also, SCE now operates under the tax accounting memorandum accounts or TAMA approved in the 2015 rate case decision. This has reduced the variability around taxes. 
As we indicated on the last earnings call, SCE is doing better than our original earnings guidance. This is reflected in the updated guidance I will discuss shortly. Also, as expected, holding company costs are higher than our original guidance as we suggested last quarter. We continue to fine-tune the level of cost needed to successfully develop our new competitive businesses without undue drag on our consolidated results. With that background, let's look specifically at third quarter results. 
For SCE, the largest positive impact on revenue is the $0.13 per share benefit related to the timing of the GRC decision. Think of this as the amount that ideally would have been recorded in the first and second quarters of last year if the GRC decision had been in effect all of 2015. The other positive drivers are revenue escalation for growth provided for in the 2015 rate case decision as well as the return on poll loading rate base. You will recall that the poll loading program is handled through a separate balancing account in the current rate case, and received rate base treatment. 
On the cost side, we are seeing expected favorable earnings contribution from the operational improvement SCE has focused on for some time. Higher depreciation and financing costs reflect the normal trends supporting SCE's capital spending program. Income tax expense is higher on higher pretax income and lower income tax benefits on property related items. Overall, SCE earnings increased $0.15 per share or 13% to $1.34 per share. 
Let's turn to the Edison International holding company, which includes the costs for Edison Energy Group. Comparisons continued to reflect the absence of earnings from the affordable housing portfolio sold at the end of last year. We also see the higher levels of support for developing our new businesses along with the higher interest expense from churning out some of the holding company debt earlier this year. Core losses were $0.05 per share and $0.02 per share higher than last year. The increase in losses are driven equally by the absence of Edison Mission Group earnings and higher Edison Energy Group costs. Underlying holding company costs are generally comparable to last year's third quarter. 
GAAP comparisons are also impacted by income of $0.13 per share from discontinued operations in the third quarter of last year with no impact on core earnings. This was related to updated estimates and tax benefits and insurance proceeds. So net-net, core earnings came in at $1.29 per share, 11% above last year. 
Please turn to Page 3. Year-to-date results are a clear picture of underlying SCE performance as well as the holding company cost trends which are relevant to our we reaffirmed core earnings guidance. The underlying drivers for SCE are similar for those for the quarter, other than the release of reserves for uncertain tax decision for the second quarter 2015 of $0.31 per share. 
On a year-to-date basis, the timing of the 2015 GRC decision is no longer a significant factor and the earnings drivers do not include the $0.13 per share timing issue I mentioned earlier. The embedded escalation in revenues and the 2015 GRC decision and the return on poll-loading rate base are the 2 key drivers. FERC revenue increases mostly to fund higher O&M and capital continue on a year-to-date basis. 
The principal cost drivers are generally consistent through the year. As noted earlier, depreciation and financing costs reflect the higher capital associated with SCE's capital spending program as well as the recovery of transmission project costs. Taxes were impacted by last year's change in uncertain tax benefits, and the general trend of passing more tax benefits the customers through the tax memorandum accounts continues. 
Turning to the EIX holding company. We have increased costs of $0.14 per share excluding noncore items. $0.09 of this variance related to 2 discrete items. The first component is $0.05 per share-related to the absence of the Edison Mission Group portfolio earnings this year. The second component is the second quarter buyout of an earnout arrangement with former shareholders of a company acquired at the end of last year. This was $0.04 per share. Excluding these discrete items, there was $0.05 per share of higher costs, which breaks down to $0.01 per share at the holding company and $0.04 per share for Edison Energy Group. 
In absolute terms, total year-to-date core costs are $0.23 per share, which reflects $0.11 per share each as a holding company and Edison Energy Group. There was also $0.01 of costs related to the residual Edison Mission Group asset. I will come back to this topic later when I talk about our updated guidance. 
Please turn to Page 4. Today, we have reaffirmed our core earnings guidance at $3.91 per share. Last quarter, we indicated full year results should be in the top half of the guidance range, and we still see an opportunity to do that. We have narrowed the guidance range to plus or minus $0.05 per share consistent with our recent practice. At the midpoint of our guidance, the outlook for SCE is $0.09 per share higher than our original 2016 guidance, and the EIX holding company is $0.09 per share less favorable. 
For SCE, we see the improvement relating largely to the higher operational cost savings and financing benefits which have been more favorable than what we included in our initial guidance last February. The footnote recap have guidance elements have changed. Also, please note that our guidance for SCE energy efficiency earnings is now $0.04 per share. This is based on updated estimates of benefits included in our September CPC filing related to energy efficiency. 
Our updated holding company guidance follows the accounting categories in the 10-Q for the focus on core results. The first category is normal holding company costs, plus residual impact from what remains of Edison Mission Group. Corporate expenses and other costs are still a little more $0.01 a month per share based on our year-to-date results. This is consistent with what we have suggested for some time. Our full year guidance for holding company costs is $0.15 per share compared to $0.12 recorded year-to-date. 
The second category reflects Edison Energy Group with full year guidance at a $0.12 per share loss. This is aligned with the $0.02 to $0.03 per share we are seeing each quarter, or $0.07 per share so far this year, excluding the buyout of the earnout provision. While we develop these businesses, we do expect continued losses early on. 
Looking at overall holding company costs, including Edison Energy Group, we will be managing our near-term activities, such that 2017 costs do not exceed 2016 guidance levels of $0.27 per share, consistent with Pedro's earlier point. When we provide 2017 earnings guidance, we plan to provide refined cost estimates for these businesses that reflect the balance between the value creation opportunity we see in the long-term and the earnings impact in the near-term. 
Our guidance continues to exclude any recoveries related to the MHI arbitration. If we do receive any meaningful award, we will account for the recovery of legal and other costs incurred to obtain the award as core earnings. This is consistent with our core treatment of these costs over the last 3 years. While a portion of an award, depending upon the amount, will be treated as nonpoor, we didn't want to provide you with of core and noncore splits in the event an award is made. Net costs incurred and not recovered from MHI totaled $48 million or $0.09 per share. 
Please turn to Page 5. I will touch on a few other key topics. The capital spending and rate base forecasts that we provided in our September 1 GRC presentation are included in the appendix of today's presentation. SCE continuously assesses how best to optimize between new capital spending opportunities that may be identified and any changes in the schedules for existing projects for an overall capital spending. SCE continues to seek approval of the memorandum account to cover roughly $200 million of early stage grid modernization capital spending forecast in 2016 and '17. If approval is not granted by late this year or early next year, it could push out the time line for ramping up grid modernization spending under the 2018 GRC. 
Transmission permitting and regulatory review remains challenging here and for utilities in other parts of the country. The $1.1 billion West of Devers project was approved by the CPUC in August, but that decision was appealed in September on environment grounds. The approval stands pending appeal. Also, alternative designs have been proposed on the CPUC review of the $600 million Mesa Substation projects that were drilled for a significant reengineering. SCE and the California ISO continue to recommend the project. These permitting and approval challenges are increasingly typical of transmission planning and part of the process, although the need for these projects is not affected by the regulatory delays that impact initial timing.  Despite these challenges, we continue to see at least $4 billion in annual SCE capital spending and roughly $2 billion of annual rate base growth in 2017 and for the foreseeable future. With almost all of that investment in the lighter side of the business, we believe it has lower investment opportunity risk as compared to utilities with high percentages of growth tied to generation investment. 
On other financial matters, SCE has a full settlement in place at the current capital structure and cost of capital, including an ROE of 10.45% for 2017. SCE's cost of capital trigger mechanism ended its last measurement period at 4.91%, just below the 5% midpoint. Under our settlement, the operation of the mechanism is suspended at this time. However, utility interest rate trends remain relevant, looking ahead to the next capital proceedings in April of next year. The moving average restarted October 1 at the spot rate of 4.26%, against what is likely for a long-term interest rates in the current rate environment.
SCE remains open to another settlement for a further extension. SCE's equity ratio for regulatory purposes remain strong at 50.4% as of September 30. SCE remains comfortable with its 48% equity capital structure and has no plans to recommend any changes in the equity ratio to the CPUC. While conservative, it helps provide the flexibility we need to support our dividend growth objective.
I want to touch briefly on financing strategy if only to reaffirm our past statements. For SCE, we plan on funding our capital program with no new equity, relying on long-term debt and preferred stock financing, as well as operating cash flow and perhaps, short-term debt as needed. At the holding company, the principal financing need this quarter was for the last E&E bondholder settlement payment of $214 million. EIX retained plenty of financial flexibility and overall financing needs remain modest at this time. 
Finally, we plan on continuing our normal practice of providing 2017 earnings guidance when we report fourth quarter and full year financial results tentatively scheduled for February 21 of next year. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. Christy, please open the line for questions.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael. So certainly, in terms of the discussion about bounding, we do intend to do that. We've already kind of said during our prepared remarks that we're going to bound that at no more than 2017 -- '16 guidance levels for EIX Parent and other. As we mo
componenttext: Michael. So certainly, in terms of the discussion about bounding, we do intend to do that. As we move through the rest of the year and we're kind of compiling all of our budget information, we'll be able to provide more detail as to exactly how that shakes out as an energy group.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: When we think about how you're trying to work on the glide path for dividend policy, you've been pretty clear and consistent. But when I look out past 2017 and I think about the GRC, the fact that productivity and financing benefits will probably all get wrapped into the next rate case decision, is it right to think about the rate base math for -- minus parent overhead and where we think you're sort of try to target Edison Energy Group back to come up with sort of 2019, 2020 theoretical earnings growth earnings numbers in order to set the kind of dividend growth policy that you'll have through that transition?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg. It's kind of early days right now to actually know what's going to happen in the GRC itself. Obviously, our dividends are all keyed off of SCE earnings. As that continues to grow with the rate base growth, you'll see a continuing ability to bring ou
componenttext: Greg. It's kind of early days right now to actually know what's going to happen in the GRC itself. Obviously, our dividends are all keyed off of SCE earnings. As that continues to grow with the rate base growth, you'll see a continuing ability to bring our dividends up over time, as Pedro said earlier. So I think that's really how we're thinking about it.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So I don't have any insights on the schedule. I think we saw 1 press report that said that ALJ was leaving or retiring. We believe the settlement terms continue to be fair but as I mentioned in my comments, we don't have a way to handicap at this point when the commission will act.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just finally, on the SCE equity ratio, I think you said it's just, it's north of 50% as of September. Is that seasonal? Do you see tracking down as you move through this rate case period, or should we imagine it holds around that level? Wha
componenttext: Okay. And then just finally, on the SCE equity ratio, I think you said it's just, it's north of 50% as of September. Is that seasonal? Do you see tracking down as you move through this rate case period, or should we imagine it holds around that level? What is your, what does the model show?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's 50.4% as of September 30, and that number is north of the 48%, that's our authorized equity ratio. We will, over time, I'm sure you see that squeeze down. Although that really does give us the flexibility to manage our capital program, our divi
componenttext: Well, it's 50.4% as of September 30, and that number is north of the 48%, that's our authorized equity ratio. We will, over time, I'm sure you see that squeeze down. Although that really does give us the flexibility to manage our capital program, our dividend program and all that, so we actually think that's a good spot to be in.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could someone -- also related topic, you mentioned, I think, West of Devers being appealed and then the Mesa Substation design being called into question. If you see -- which year were those projects expected to benefit the most? And s
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could someone -- also related topic, you mentioned, I think, West of Devers being appealed and then the Mesa Substation design being called into question. If you see -- which year were those projects expected to benefit the most? And sort of a flip to the right, is it an '17 issue? Is it more an '18 issue? Can you just give us a little more color and then maybe how one might backfill it?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So those projects, both of those projects are being reviewed by the CPUC. I will say the review is not whether or not those projects are needed, the review is about exactly how those projects should be build out. And we are still assessing what the
componenttext: Sure. So those projects, both of those projects are being reviewed by the CPUC. I will say the review is not whether or not those projects are needed, the review is about exactly how those projects should be build out. And we are still assessing what the impact would be on the schedule and the costs. It certainly, reengineering a project could potentially cause it to be delayed. But there are some suggestions as to different types of projects that could actually increase the costs of those projects. But we're currently in the process of looking at what the different proposals are, and whether or not we need to start engineering around some of those different proposals. Mesa's a very good example, that, in that case, other alternatives have been proposed but in fact, the California ISO has said that each of the alternatives that have been proposed, either don't mean the need or don't meet the time requirements.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 1 global comment on this, just to summarize it. This is not a question of if, it's just a question of when.
componenttext: Just 1 global comment on this, just to summarize it. This is not a question of if, it's just a question of when.

componenttext: So in the current plan, were these '17 projects primarily or further out?

But the need dates were like 2020, 2021 for most of these projects CPUC co  spread over the entire period. Just to note, Jonathan, we have not changed any of our forecast at this point while we wait for those decisions.

componenttext: Is that because you're assuming you'll find other things to kind of bring forward, or some other reasons? You're just waiting to get the outcome before you make a change? I don't know what you're implying.

componenttext: Well, two things. Certainly, we do look for ways to we redeploy our capital when something is delayed, but secondly also, that we will be in a process as we get more information to update our numbers.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Praful Mehta of Citigroup.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to Edison Energy again. And I wanted to more understand, from a cash cost perspective, given there's a bunch of investment happening here, I'm not sure if the earnings -- the earnings impact that you're talking about reflects what O&M expense,
componenttext: Going back to Edison Energy again. And I wanted to more understand, from a cash cost perspective, given there's a bunch of investment happening here, I'm not sure if the earnings -- the earnings impact that you're talking about reflects what O&M expense, is it depreciation on investments, just if you could give some color on what the cash costs you expect there, and how does that profile kind of look between earnings and cash?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So at the end of last year, we did deploy some capital, some cash to purchase the 3 companies at Edison Energy. On a go-forward basis, we have a service model, we are focused on providing energy as a service, so the capital needs of those companies from a
componenttext: So at the end of last year, we did deploy some capital, some cash to purchase the 3 companies at Edison Energy. On a go-forward basis, we have a service model, we are focused on providing energy as a service, so the capital needs of those companies from an investment perspective is not gigantic. There are some operating expenses, so of course, that's why you're seeing the drag at the holding company -- in the holding company costs. The numbers themselves are pretty immaterial relative to the overall Edison International structure. So I mean I think that kind of bounces it for you. I don't know if these are [indiscernible] to say.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that captures and given the questions that I think we've all got in from a number of you as we chatted through September, we wanted to make sure we provided some near-term clarity as to what the overall earnings impact was at the total consoli
componenttext: No. I think that captures and given the questions that I think we've all got in from a number of you as we chatted through September, we wanted to make sure we provided some near-term clarity as to what the overall earnings impact was at the total consolidated EIX level. That's what he focused on that today. And then we'll add more detail we can provide first in February when the issue 2017 guidance. But I think you're also getting to what's the nature of the business itself and what's more of a business model question. And that goes to providing a detailed business plan to our investors, which I mentioned in my comments, we expect to do no later than 12 months from now. So I think that will clarify our best thinking at that point and influenced by feedback we've been gaining from customers over the last few months, thus thinking in terms of what is that model and what do we see as some of the key milestones and outlays over the years ahead.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. On the bounding, it's helpful, I definitely appreciate that.
componenttext: Got you. On the bounding, it's helpful, I definitely appreciate that.

componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on Slide 5, you mentioned here the $4 billion of capital spend with $2 billion annual rate base increase well into the next decade. Now as you're growing rate base, clearly as a percentage of rate base, that growth is dropping off. So is this a signal
componenttext: And on Slide 5, you mentioned here the $4 billion of capital spend with $2 billion annual rate base increase well into the next decade. Now as you're growing rate base, clearly as a percentage of rate base, that growth is dropping off. So is this a signal to indicate a drop-off in the percentage growth? Or is it more to say that this is the base case and there is more incremental to that to kind of maintain a certain percentage as well?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I think that's a message you've heard consistently in several other earnings calls and in the past. I think what we said is we see a continued case supporting 4, at least $4 billion a year in CapEx. I think we've acknowledged in the past that assuming
componenttext: As I think that's a message you've heard consistently in several other earnings calls and in the past. I think what we said is we see a continued case supporting 4, at least $4 billion a year in CapEx. I think we've acknowledged in the past that assuming that, that continues which we see that opportunity, that provides a floor for growth. And to the extent that we're investing at that, call it $4 billion, $4 billion-ish level, the denominator grows, the percent increase from the denominator starts tailoring down. That's said, you saw in our rate case application that the request that we provided, if we got the total request, which we don't expect we'll go get 100% of that but we provided a very strong case, that rate case 4 request will take us to $5 billion, which will then be a step-up in that rate. So I guess that the final point I'll make you is think about it as a floor, but as we look up the California opportunity, that's a really interesting opportunity over certainly the decade ahead. And as I mentioned in my comments, we're still, not just we as SCE, but we, the state, are still trying to get their arms around what SP 32 really mean? What is the nature of that opportunity? When you have to reduce greenhouse gases more than 40% than from what we are today, that's going to work were amount of infrastructure. Early to say how much of that might be, no infrastructure translator rate case infrastructure on the customer side or by other entities. It will certainly imply a good opportunity in terms of the usage of the grid. But I think net-net, when you look at SP32, when you look at some of the other upsides around, items like the storage item that Julian asked about earlier, we do see continued support for investing at its least at floor $4 billion. And to the extent that we're only investing at that floor, then yes, you'll see the ratio ease up overtime. So does that make sense?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from the line of Michael Lapides of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And the next question is from the line of Michael Lapides of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: A couple of questions, I'll start on the nonutility or nonregulated side of the business. Have you communicated or is this what's coming a year from now, what your anticipated goal is in terms of when you expect this investment to generate earnings power for the company or when you expect this investment to generate positive, not negative, free cash for the company?

componenttext: Got it. And then coming back to SCE, there's the potential at some point in the coming months or so that you'll get results in the Mitsubishi arbitration. And half of those proceeds would come to the utility and the other half would go to customers. How do you think about how you would utilize those proceeds, the proceeds that come back to the utility?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think and I think Pedro might've mentioned this in his comments, is that we will really retain on the utility and offset to the extent that we were using short-term debt to really fund the capital program that we see, which is as you know from the GR
componenttext: So I think and I think Pedro might've mentioned this in his comments, is that we will really retain on the utility and offset to the extent that we were using short-term debt to really fund the capital program that we see, which is as you know from the GRC, pretty substantial.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But you'e already got a pretty healthy equity later at the utility and you've got some runway. And I assume the Mitsubishi cash, if there's any cash, isn't going to just come overnight. It might take a little while for it to come in. So in that tim
componenttext: Right. But you'e already got a pretty healthy equity later at the utility and you've got some runway. And I assume the Mitsubishi cash, if there's any cash, isn't going to just come overnight. It might take a little while for it to come in. So in that time frame, the equity layer continues to grow. I'm just curious about -- are you commenting on the short-term debt side, that you're worried your short-term debt balances is getting a little too healthy or too thick? Or is there just less balance sheet capacity than maybe I'm thinking about?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't think our short-term debt is getting too thick. I mean you can see from our financial statements, we're in a pretty comfortable spot. But over time, I think it's just a nice place to be to have that capacity. If we were to get an award, we don
componenttext: No. I don't think our short-term debt is getting too thick. I mean you can see from our financial statements, we're in a pretty comfortable spot. But over time, I think it's just a nice place to be to have that capacity. If we were to get an award, we don't know that we're going to get an award, but if we were to get an award and at any substantial size, I think it would provide another layer of certainty or cushion as we build out our program.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then last think just related to that, if you get an award, is that taxable?

componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: So whatever the number is, that comes back to SCE. What you're really getting is 60%, 65% of that level?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Ali Agha of SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Ali Agha of SunTrust.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, you're implementing the SONGS settlement, as per the terms of the settlement for a while now. And so from a practical point of view, if the commission decided to reopen it, can you be sort of put that need back, genie back in the bottle gi
componenttext: First question, you're implementing the SONGS settlement, as per the terms of the settlement for a while now. And so from a practical point of view, if the commission decided to reopen it, can you be sort of put that need back, genie back in the bottle given how far down the road we've already come? I mean how does that work conceptually if this thing was revealed?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're talking about the genie in the bottle, we've talked about to unscramble the engage or put the toothpaste back in the tube. So I think that would be one of the challenges where the commission to decide to reopen the settlement. And of course, if the
componenttext: You're talking about the genie in the bottle, we've talked about to unscramble the engage or put the toothpaste back in the tube. So I think that would be one of the challenges where the commission to decide to reopen the settlement. And of course, if they did that, we believe strongly in the litigation decisions that we have and we would reassert those. But you're pointing out one of the implementation challenges, if the commission were to reopen, it's a -- would be very tough to do. And as I mentioned, like I mentioned in my comments, we are -- we refunded or on the way to refunding total $1.6 billion. So big amounts to stake here benefiting customers.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Second question, when you're benchmarking your costs versus your relevant peer group, where do you see yourselves standing, which quartile right now? And really, mean for the last couple of rate case cycles, in particular, you've been able to benefit
componenttext: Yes. Second question, when you're benchmarking your costs versus your relevant peer group, where do you see yourselves standing, which quartile right now? And really, mean for the last couple of rate case cycles, in particular, you've been able to benefit from the nonrate case years by coming in with better costs and keeping that upside. How much more is left in that process when you benchmark yourselves and see where you stand today?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I might stay pretty high-level on this one. Let's say we're probably in the middle of the pack, some areas a little better, some areas a little worse. We pointed investors to our rate case filing and the pieces that we have some level of confidence on
componenttext: So I might stay pretty high-level on this one. Let's say we're probably in the middle of the pack, some areas a little better, some areas a little worse. We pointed investors to our rate case filing and the pieces that we have some level of confidence on when we were filing our rate case. Of course we put on the rate case in obligation to do that for customers. We said that we will continue to work at this. We have not quantified for investors what that additional opportunity is or the timing for it, partly because we're continuously doing that work, Ali, and that's a work in progress. The other comment I'd make, though, is beyond just looking at what it means for SCE today, to benchmark itself against the folks who are in the top quartile already or even best in class, that's where the while industry and frankly the whole economy has set it, certainly over the decade ahead for us here, technology is going to be opening up some pretty powerful opportunities to reshape how a lot of American work is done. And I think even the folks who are best-in-class in our industry or in other industries, are going to see continued opportunities for improvement, whether it's a back-office technologies, or an artificial intelligence or the impact of other hardware and software in various parts of our business, I just see that as a continuing opportunity for all of us in the industry and across the economy. And so I don't think we're at a point yet where we stop. So it's better to be a continuing theme for us but we haven't quantified what that could mean yet.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Maybe one last question, I'm sorry, if I could. You may have different valuation benchmarks on how you're looking at the Edison Energy businesses, obviously different businesses. But as you know, your stock craves on a BE multiple, so earnings
componenttext: Understood. Maybe one last question, I'm sorry, if I could. You may have different valuation benchmarks on how you're looking at the Edison Energy businesses, obviously different businesses. But as you know, your stock craves on a BE multiple, so earnings matter. So in that context, how sensitive is it for you to at least get those businesses to breakeven on earnings so you're not getting penalized, as I believe you are, by those losses flowing through your earnings statements?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, Ali. And I'll kick it off and Maria might have other thoughts. Yes, you're right, I think that EIX does trade largely on SCE earnings, that is the core of the business. And today, the Edison Energy Group activities are nonmaterial
componenttext: Thanks for the question, Ali. And I'll kick it off and Maria might have other thoughts. Yes, you're right, I think that EIX does trade largely on SCE earnings, that is the core of the business. And today, the Edison Energy Group activities are nonmaterial relative to the broad EIX story. We are excited about the opportunity, as I've mentioned earlier, we are sensitive, recognize that investors look at earnings in PE. And as we develop that business plan that we'll share over the next 12 months, our goal is to make that as transparent as possible because we recognize that we have a responsibility here to explain that business case to investors and make it one that you can get your arms around. In a specific case of that is Edison Energy, this is getting a little ahead of our [indiscernible] here but just to provide a little bit of color. We view that as an energy as a service kind of business. The business that we have today basically have a number of customers, contracts can span from 1 to several years. We've expect that to be a book of business that we could describe to our investors and provide metrics around the texture of that portfolio, the tenure of it, what contract volumes or what years, measures of backlog, et cetera. But at the end of the day, we would hope would -- would expect to provide some good level of confidence around continuing cash flow streams, continuing earning streams. So I just described something at pretty high-level here. Expect us to put more fancy paper as we develop our business plan and share it with you. But we're thinking about that in our way and frankly, in large part, because of the good feedback we've gotten from a number of you, about how to reconcile new businesses that -- with the core story and how the core story is valued, EIX and SCE. Maria, anything to add, or?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just touch on I think one of the earlier questions from Jonathan about the equity ratio, I mean, I understand you like the flexibility, you talked about dividend growth and everything else. But when you go from a 48% to 50% equity ratio on the
componenttext: If I could just touch on I think one of the earlier questions from Jonathan about the equity ratio, I mean, I understand you like the flexibility, you talked about dividend growth and everything else. But when you go from a 48% to 50% equity ratio on the rate base that you guys have, I mean, it's a significant driver of earnings. And if the commissions are able to give you that flexibility, why not look to set it at 50% and still enjoy that flexibility because right now it looks like your losing $0.18 to $0.20 of earnings?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thanks for the question. We are comfortable at the place we are right now at 48% authorized, yet we're a little higher than that at the current moment, but that will work over time as we continue to expand our capital program. I mean that flexibility i
componenttext: So thanks for the question. We are comfortable at the place we are right now at 48% authorized, yet we're a little higher than that at the current moment, but that will work over time as we continue to expand our capital program. I mean that flexibility is really important. We're trying to balance a lot of things in the context of we want to be able to deploy the capital that we need to get the grid modernized, to focus on safety and reliability, all those things that customers need, and then also balance that against customer rate as well. So we're doing a lot of things. The 48% level of authorized equity rate actually does fit in with the overall objectives that we're trying to achieve. And we think that it provides us with the right amount of flexibility over time.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Could you use the parent company that also provides flexibility? Or you're just really looking at flexibility at the utility? I'm thinking maybe the parent could provide some additional equity to the utility if you were -- had a huge capital program?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think that the answer is, for the most part, we look at these as fairly separate tracks. There's just a number of a -- a portion of our revenue requirement, and a program, a large portion that flows through the General Rate Case. There are individ
componenttext: Okay. I think that the answer is, for the most part, we look at these as fairly separate tracks. There's just a number of a -- a portion of our revenue requirement, and a program, a large portion that flows through the General Rate Case. There are individual, special-purpose programs like a charge rating which is going through a separate track. And so those are fairly independent. Perhaps, the 1 point of more interaction that's still being defined is around the whole topic of grid modernization. I think it's fair to say that in the beginning when the commission first set up the distribution resource plan proceeding or DRP, that was intended to provide policy level guidance that would then feed into the request of each utility in their general rate cases. We do have a unique situation with SCE's rate case in that just the timing of our rate case is such that we had to file a request before we have a final decision in the DRP proceeding. The commission has recognized that and so some interaction there, but in the meantime, we're very focused on providing the testimony and the high-quality testimony in the GRC proceedings. And again we're encouraged by the comment President Picker made about wanting to stay on the overall time lines. Looking at Kevin Pane and Ron in case they have anything to add there.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would that, this is Ron Nichols, I would add that the commission in their DRP proceeding, guidance here recently, that in Q2 of 2017, that they expect to provide some more guidance on grid modernization investment levels. So we're expecting that w
componenttext: Well, I would that, this is Ron Nichols, I would add that the commission in their DRP proceeding, guidance here recently, that in Q2 of 2017, that they expect to provide some more guidance on grid modernization investment levels. So we're expecting that will give us a better clue. We hope to reinforce it with regard to where we're headed, but that's at least identifies the fact we've asked for a memorandum account for this, and they're now finally coming out with some time line for some guidance.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our next question is from the line of [indiscernible] from Research Consulting.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering on your numbers on the greenhouse gas emissions and I come to a very interesting conclusion, which is that the opportunity for investment in the electric grid infrastructure around electric vehicles is stunningly high. Meaning, 40% [p
componenttext: I was just wondering on your numbers on the greenhouse gas emissions and I come to a very interesting conclusion, which is that the opportunity for investment in the electric grid infrastructure around electric vehicles is stunningly high. Meaning, 40% [ph] greenhouse gas emissions from power plants has to got to cut in half by law, so 10% of the 40%, let's assume industrial contributed another 10% out of the 40%, and commercial customers contribute 5%, maybe 10% of that. That means 15% [ph] of that 40% has to come from the transportation area. And rough numbers suggest that 10 million cars being taken off the road, which means several fix. One, a massive increase in power generation, most likely on the renewables side and two, massive distribution line expansion and massive infrastructure investment in electrical vehicle charging stations. Am I in the ballpark?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you just define 1 potential scenario, but I think there are many. And the reality is that the state is just starting to get its arms around how this all really will shakeout. And I will tell you some of the interesting questions here are how mu
componenttext: So I think you just define 1 potential scenario, but I think there are many. And the reality is that the state is just starting to get its arms around how this all really will shakeout. And I will tell you some of the interesting questions here are how much of this will be done by the state going to the kind of analysis that you just went through there and allocating that out on a sector by sector basis, how much of it will be done by relying on more market forces and seeing how the markets brings out the best opportunities. So I'll probably stop short on commenting on your specific scenario there. But really, come back to the basic message, which is no matter which way we cut it, and we're doing our own homework on this right now as they're state agencies, but no matter how we cut it, we see electrification of a lot of the economy being absolutely needed. Whether it's a you're a quick math there in terms of the impact in transportation and some of the other factors, whether it's different math, different proportions coming from different sectors, even within transportation, how much comes from passenger light-duty light vehicles, how much comes from heavier duty, lots of questions that the state needs grapple. With in the end, I mean which way you cut it, it will require a fair amount of electrification and therefore really, cement the absolute necessity of having a strong and modern grid as a center of it all to move that power around. So that's the focus and I think we will all be learning a lot over the course of the next 2 [ph] years here as we march our way to the state being able to meet the expectation of the law 14 years from now.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's one thing I would point to at least, probably Utilities Commission has come up with a request back middle of September, came out with a ruling to have all 3 of the investment utilities make a filing January 20, 2017 on our ideas with
componenttext: Well, I think there's one thing I would point to at least, probably Utilities Commission has come up with a request back middle of September, came out with a ruling to have all 3 of the investment utilities make a filing January 20, 2017 on our ideas with regard to what could be done, both in programs and investments to accelerate transportation electrification. That's only one piece, admittedly. But at least, there is, from that end, a push towards doing that. It's pretty out-of-the-box thinking with regards to this. And that will create opportunities potentially for investment, and whether we make the investment or other parties, third parties make an investment, greater increase in use of our grid, and benefit the spread in those costs over higher amount of kilowatt hour sales. As to the larger scale, the California Resources Board is still working on a long-term plan that includes all the other sectors, but they don't have a hard time on that yet.
