componenttext: So you'll -- you can see that, and it's disclosed in sort of the edit the -- the parent section of the cash flows. But really, the bulk of what we spent is that $100 million last year to buy the 3 companies that are basically Edison Energy.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then coming back to SCE, there's the potential at some point in the coming months or so that you'll get results in the Mitsubishi arbitration, and half of those proceeds would come to the utility and the other half would go to customers. How d
componenttext: Got it. And then coming back to SCE, there's the potential at some point in the coming months or so that you'll get results in the Mitsubishi arbitration, and half of those proceeds would come to the utility and the other half would go to customers. How do you think about how you would utilize those proceeds, the proceeds that come back to the utility?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think -- and I think actually, Pedro, might have mentioned this in his comments, is that we would really retain that at the utility and offset to the extent that we were using short-term debt to really fund the capital program that we see, which is,
componenttext: So I think -- and I think actually, Pedro, might have mentioned this in his comments, is that we would really retain that at the utility and offset to the extent that we were using short-term debt to really fund the capital program that we see, which is, as you know from the GRC, pretty substantial.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But you've already got a pretty healthy equity layer at the utility, and you've got some runway. And I assume the Mitsubishi cash, if there is any cash, isn't going to just come overnight. It may take a little while for it to come in. So in that ti
componenttext: Right. But you've already got a pretty healthy equity layer at the utility, and you've got some runway. And I assume the Mitsubishi cash, if there is any cash, isn't going to just come overnight. It may take a little while for it to come in. So in that time frame, the equity layer continues to grow. I'm just curious about -- are you commenting on the short-term debts, that you're worried your short-term debt balance is getting a little too healthy or too thick? Or is there just less balance sheet capacity than maybe I'm thinking about?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think our short-term debt is getting too thick. I mean, you can see from our financial statements we're in a pretty comfortable spot. But over time, I think it's just a nice place to be to have that capacity. If we were to get an award, we don
componenttext: No, I don't think our short-term debt is getting too thick. I mean, you can see from our financial statements we're in a pretty comfortable spot. But over time, I think it's just a nice place to be to have that capacity. If we were to get an award, we don't know that we're going to get an award, but if we were to get an award and -- of any substantial size, I think it would provide another layer of certainty or cushion as we build out our capital program.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last thing just related to that, if you get an award, is that taxable?
componenttext: Okay. And then last thing just related to that, if you get an award, is that taxable?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: So whatever the number is that comes back to SCE, what you're really getting is 60%, 65% of that level?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Ali Agha of SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Ali Agha of SunTrust.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, Pedro, you've been obviously implementing the SONGS settlement as per the terms of the settlement for a while now. And so from a practical point of view, if the commission decided to reopen it can we sort of put that back -- genie back in
componenttext: First question, Pedro, you've been obviously implementing the SONGS settlement as per the terms of the settlement for a while now. And so from a practical point of view, if the commission decided to reopen it can we sort of put that back -- genie back in the bottle given how far down the road we have already come? I mean, how does that work conceptually if this thing were to be real?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're talking about the genie in the bottle. We've talked about it'd be tough to unscramble the egg or put the toothpaste back in the tube. So I think that would be one of the challenges were the commission to decide to reopen the settlement. And of cour
componenttext: You're talking about the genie in the bottle. We've talked about it'd be tough to unscramble the egg or put the toothpaste back in the tube. So I think that would be one of the challenges were the commission to decide to reopen the settlement. And of course, if they did that, we believe strongly in the litigation positions that we had, and we would reassert those. But you're pointing out one of the implementation challenges if the commission were to reopen. It'll be very tough to do. And as I mentioned -- like I mentioned in my comments, we've -- we are -- we've refunded or on the way to refunding total of $1.6 billion. So big amounts at stake here benefiting customers.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Second question, when you're benchmarking your costs versus your relevant peer group, where do you see yourself standing, which quartile right now? And really the trust being that for the last couple of rate case cycles in particular, you've been abl
componenttext: Yes. Second question, when you're benchmarking your costs versus your relevant peer group, where do you see yourself standing, which quartile right now? And really the trust being that for the last couple of rate case cycles in particular, you've been able to benefit from the nonrate case years by coming in with better costs and keeping that upside. How much more is left in that process when you benchmark yourselves and see where you stand today?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to say pretty high level on this one. I'd say we're probably in the middle of the pack, some areas a little better, some areas a little worse. We've pointed investors to our rate case filing and the pieces that we have some level of confidence o
componenttext: I'm going to say pretty high level on this one. I'd say we're probably in the middle of the pack, some areas a little better, some areas a little worse. We've pointed investors to our rate case filing and the pieces that we have some level of confidence on when we were filing our rate case. Of course, we put in the rate case from an obligation to -- for customers. We said that we will continue to work at this. We have not quantified for our investors what that additional opportunity is or the timing for it partly because we're continuously doing that work, Ali, and that's a work in progress. The other comment I'd make though is beyond just looking at what it means for SCE today to benchmark itself against the folks, some of the top quartile already or even best-in-class, that versus where I think the whole industry and, frankly, the whole economy is headed. Certainly over the decade ahead for us here, technology is going to be opening up some pretty powerful opportunities to reshape how a lot of American work is done. And I think even the folks who are best in class in our industry or in other industries are going to see continued opportunities for improvement, whether it's back-office technologies or artificial intelligence or the impact of other hardware and software in various parts of our business, I just see that as a continuing opportunity for all of us in the industry and across the economy. And so I don't think we're at a point yet where we stop. So expect that to be a continuing theme for us, but we haven't quantified what that could mean yet.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Pedro, one last question, I'm sorry, if I could. You may have different valuation benchmarks on how you're looking at the Edison Energy businesses, obviously different businesses. But as you know, your stock trades on a P/E multiple, so earnin
componenttext: Understood. Pedro, one last question, I'm sorry, if I could. You may have different valuation benchmarks on how you're looking at the Edison Energy businesses, obviously different businesses. But as you know, your stock trades on a P/E multiple, so earnings matter. So in that context, how sensitive is it for you to at least get those businesses to breakeven on earnings so you're not getting penalized, as I believe you are, by those losses flowing through your earning statements?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, Ali. And I'll kick it off, and Maria might have other thoughts. Yes, you're right, I think that EIX does trade largely on SCE earnings. That is the core of the business. And today, the Edison Energy Group activities are nonmateria
componenttext: Thanks for the question, Ali. And I'll kick it off, and Maria might have other thoughts. Yes, you're right, I think that EIX does trade largely on SCE earnings. That is the core of the business. And today, the Edison Energy Group activities are nonmaterial relative to the broad EIX story. We are excited about the opportunity. As I mentioned earlier, we are sensitive, recognize that investors look at earnings in P/E. And as we develop that business plan that we'll share over the next 12 months, our goal is to make that as transparent as possible because we recognize that we have a responsibility here to explain the business case to investors and make it one that you all can get your arms around. In the specific case of Edison Energy, this is getting a little ahead of our ski tips here but just to provide a little bit of color, we view that as an energy as a service kind of business. The business that we have today basically have a number of customers, contracts that can span from 1 to several years. We'd expect it to be a book of business that we could describe to our investors and provide metrics around the texture of that portfolio, the tenure of it, what contract volumes over what years, measures of backlog, et cetera. But at the end of the day, we would hope would and would expect it would provide some good level of confidence around continuing cash flow streams, continuing earning streams. So I just described something at pretty high level here. Expect us to put more pen to paper as we develop the business plan and share it with you. But we're thinking about that in a way and, frankly, in large part because of the good feedback we've gotten from a number of you about how to reconcile new businesses that -- with the core story and how the core story is valued at EIX and at SCE. Maria, anything to add, or?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't think so. I think you captured it.
componenttext: No. I don't think so. I think you captured it.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Anthony Crowdell of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Anthony Crowdell of Jefferies.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, Pedro or Maria, huge improvement over the last couple calls. Just -- If I could just touch on I think one of the earlier questions from Jonathan about the equity ratio, I mean, I understand you like the flexibility, you talk about dividend growth a
componenttext: First, Pedro or Maria, huge improvement over the last couple calls. Just -- If I could just touch on I think one of the earlier questions from Jonathan about the equity ratio, I mean, I understand you like the flexibility, you talk about dividend growth and everything else. But when you go from a 48% to 50% equity ratio on the rate base that you guys have, I mean it's a significant driver of earnings. And if the commissions is able to give you that flexibility, why not look to set it at a 50% and still enjoy that flexibility? Because right now it looks like you're losing $0.18 to $0.20 of earnings.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. We are comfortable at the place we are right now, 48% authorized. Yes, we're a little higher than that at the current moment. But with that, we'll work down over time as we continue to expand our capital program. I think that flex
componenttext: Thanks for the question. We are comfortable at the place we are right now, 48% authorized. Yes, we're a little higher than that at the current moment. But with that, we'll work down over time as we continue to expand our capital program. I think that flexibility is really important. We're trying to balance a lot of things in the context of we want the -- we want to be able to deploy the capital that we need to get the grid modernized, to focus on safety and reliability, all the things that our customers need and then also balance that against customer rates as well. So we're doing a lot of things. The 48% level authorized equity rate actually does fit in with the overall objectives that we're trying to achieve. And we think that it provides us with the right amount of flexibility over time.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you use the parent company to also provide flexibility? Or you're just really looking at flexibility at the utility? I'm thinking maybe the parent could provide some additional equity to the utility if you were -- had a huge capital program.
componenttext: Could you use the parent company to also provide flexibility? Or you're just really looking at flexibility at the utility? I'm thinking maybe the parent could provide some additional equity to the utility if you were -- had a huge capital program.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, EIX has some balance sheet flexibility. I think we'd have to think about that over time in terms of where would be the most appropriate place to provide that sort of backing.
componenttext: Certainly, EIX has some balance sheet flexibility. I think we'd have to think about that over time in terms of where would be the most appropriate place to provide that sort of backing.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Travis Miller of MorningStar.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Travis Miller of MorningStar.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering with, obviously, all these initiatives going on in California smart grid, all the other stuff, storage transmission, even those delays there, how much is the timing of the GRC decision dependent on any of those things happening? How long a
componenttext: I was wondering with, obviously, all these initiatives going on in California smart grid, all the other stuff, storage transmission, even those delays there, how much is the timing of the GRC decision dependent on any of those things happening? How long along their various timelines?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you mean from a process and staff workload perspective or?
componenttext: Do you mean from a process and staff workload perspective or?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of your investment proposal and the commission's various needs to approve various types of initiatives.
componenttext: In terms of your investment proposal and the commission's various needs to approve various types of initiatives.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the answer is for the most part we look at these as fairly separate tracks. It may have a -- there's just a number of -- or a portion of our revenue requirement and our programs, a large portion that flows through the General Rate Case. There
componenttext: I think that the answer is for the most part we look at these as fairly separate tracks. It may have a -- there's just a number of -- or a portion of our revenue requirement and our programs, a large portion that flows through the General Rate Case. There are individual special-purpose programs like Charge Ready, which is going through a separate track. And so those are fairly independent. Perhaps, the one point of more interaction that's still being defined is around the whole topic of grid modernization. I think it's fair to say that in the beginning when the commission first set up the distribution resource plan proceeding or DRP that was intended to provide policy-level guidance that would then feed into the request of each utility in their General Rate Cases. We do have a unique situation with SCE's rate case in just the timing of our rate case is such that we had to file a request before we have a final decision in the DRP proceeding. I believe the commission has recognized that. And so some interaction there, but in the meantime, we're very focused on providing the testimony and high-quality testimony in the GRC proceedings. And again, we're encouraged by the comments that President Picker made about wanting to stay on the overall timelines. Looking at Kevin Payne and Ron Nichols in case they have anything to add there or if I covered it.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would add that -- this is Ron Nichols. I would add that the commission in their DRP proceeding gave guidance here recently that in Q2 of 2017 that they expect to provide some more guidance on grid modernization investment levels. So we're expectin
componenttext: Well, I would add that -- this is Ron Nichols. I would add that the commission in their DRP proceeding gave guidance here recently that in Q2 of 2017 that they expect to provide some more guidance on grid modernization investment levels. So we're expecting that will give us a better clue. We hope reinforcements with regard to where we're headed, but that at least identifies the fact we've asked for a memorandum of account for this, and they are now finally coming out with some -- the timeline for some guidance.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Lasan Johong of Auvila Research Consulting.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Lasan Johong of Auvila Research Consulting.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just running through your numbers on the greenhouse gas emissions. And I've come to a very interesting conclusion, which is that the opportunity for investments in the electric grid infrastructure around electric vehicles is stunningly high, meaning
componenttext: I was just running through your numbers on the greenhouse gas emissions. And I've come to a very interesting conclusion, which is that the opportunity for investments in the electric grid infrastructure around electric vehicles is stunningly high, meaning 20% greenhouse gas emissions from power plants has to get cut in half by law. So that's 10% of the 40%. Let's assume industrial has contributed another 10% out of the 40%, and commercial customers contribute 5%, maybe 10% max. That means 15% of that 40% has to come from the transportation area. And rough numbers suggest that 10 million cars being taken off the road, which means several things: one, a massive increase in power generation, most likely on the renewables side; and two, massive transmission and distribution line expansion and massive infrastructure investments in electrical vehicle charging stations. Am I in the ballpark?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you just defined one potential scenario, but I think there are many. And the reality is that the State is just starting to get its arms around how this all really will shake out. And I'll tell you, some of the interesting questions here are how
componenttext: So I think you just defined one potential scenario, but I think there are many. And the reality is that the State is just starting to get its arms around how this all really will shake out. And I'll tell you, some of the interesting questions here are how much of this will be done by the State going to the kind of analysis that you just went through there and in allocating that out on a sector-by-sector basis how much of it will be done by relying on more market forces and seeing how the markets brings out the best opportunities. So I'll probably stop short of commenting on your specific scenario there. But really, come back to the basic message, which is no matter which way we cut it -- and we're doing our own homework on this right now as our various state agencies, but no matter which way we cut it, we see electrification of a lot of the economy being absolutely needed. Now whether it's your quick math there in terms of the impact in transportation some of the effectors or whether it's different math, different proportions coming from different sectors, even within transportation, how much comes from passenger light-duty light vehicles, how much comes from heavier duty. I think it's -- lots of questions that the State needs to grapple with. But again, any which way you cut it, it will require a fair amount of electrification and therefore really cement the absolute necessity of having a strong and modern grid as the center of it all to move that power around. So that's the focus, and I think we will all be learning a lot over the course of the next 2 years here as we march our way to the state being able to meet the expectation of the law 14 years from now.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: When do you think the state's going to have some sort of an implementation plan to be able to get to the numbers by 2030?
componenttext: When do you think the state's going to have some sort of an implementation plan to be able to get to the numbers by 2030?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I hope it's sooner rather than later, but I don't think that we've seen any specific date come out some of the key agencies here. Ron Nichols, anything you'd add there?
componenttext: I hope it's sooner rather than later, but I don't think that we've seen any specific date come out some of the key agencies here. Ron Nichols, anything you'd add there?

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's -- I think there's one thing I would point to at least, that the Public Utilities Commission has come up with a request back middle of September, came out with a ruling to have all 3 of the investor-owned utilities make a filing January 20,
componenttext: Well, there's -- I think there's one thing I would point to at least, that the Public Utilities Commission has come up with a request back middle of September, came out with a ruling to have all 3 of the investor-owned utilities make a filing January 20, 2017, on our ideas with regard to what could be done both in programs and investments to accelerate transportation electrification. That's only one piece, admittedly. But there is -- at least, there is, from that end, a push towards doing that. And they've asked us to be pretty out-of-the-box thinking with regard to this, and that will create opportunities potentially for investment. And whether we make the investment or other parties -- third parties make an investment, greater increase in use of our grid and benefit of spreading those costs over a higher amount of kilowatt hour sales. As to the larger scale, the California Resources Board is still working on a longer-term plan that includes all the other sectors, but they don't have a hard timing on that yet.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of work to be done in the state.
componenttext: A lot of work to be done in the state.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That was the last question. I will now turn the call back to Mr. Scott Cunningham.
componenttext: Okay. That was the last question. I will now turn the call back to Mr. Scott Cunningham.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Christy. And thanks, everyone, for participating, and don't hesitate to give us a call if you have any questions. And we look forward to seeing many of you at the EEI financial conference next week. Good evening.
componenttext: Thanks, Christy. And thanks, everyone, for participating, and don't hesitate to give us a call if you have any questions. And we look forward to seeing many of you at the EEI financial conference next week. Good evening.

headline: Edison International, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that concludes today's conference. Thank you all for participating. You may now all disconnect.
componenttext: And that concludes today's conference. Thank you all for participating. You may now all disconnect.
